"I heard Sophia donated quite a sum?" Vincent murmured with satisfaction.

Margaret nodded eagerly. "The university said it was a significant amount."

Brandon's grip on his cane trembled. "Our Sophia has really made us proud."

As soon as they stepped onto the field, a staff member approached.

"Mr. Lowell and family? Please follow me."

They were escorted to the VIP section at the front.

Vincent's eyes widened.

They were seated right beside the Langley family!

Richard Langley and Victoria Langley sat regally in the center, flanked by their six sons like a constellation of stars.

Vincent nearly rose from his wheelchair in excitement.

"Mr. Langley, I'm—"

Before he could finish, icy glares pierced him.

The entire Langley family turned in unison, their gazes sharp as blades.

The air froze instantly.

Cold sweat trickled down Vincent's back, but he stiffened his spine.

Sitting beside the Langley patriarch—what an honor!

He adjusted his collar smugly, his resentment toward his daughter fading slightly.

But Margaret stared fixedly at Victoria's profile.

That face... Why did it look so much like Evelyn Laurent?

A chill ran through her. Her fingers trembled uncontrollably.
###Chapter 257

Margaret Hill's pupils constricted sharply. Her fingernails dug into her palms unconsciously.

An absurd thought exploded in her mind.

Could Evelyn Laurent be Victoria Langley's daughter?

She shook her head violently, leaving crescent-shaped marks on her palms.

Impossible.

That wretched girl's records clearly stated her parents were country bumpkins.

How could a prestigious family like the Langleys have rural roots?

Margaret took a deep breath, forcing herself to calm down.

She must be overthinking things because of Evelyn's recent antics.

Smoothing her dress, she sat gracefully beside Vincent Lowell, her eyes gleaming with anticipation.

This was Harvard University's Awards Ceremony.

Only a select few parents received invitations.

And they were seated right beside the Langley family.

What did that signify?

Margaret's lips curved upward involuntarily.

Sophia had truly brought honor to the Lowell name this time.

The sound of footsteps grew louder across the field.

Sophia Lowell walked amidst the crowd, her face as pale as paper.

A sense of impending doom weighed on her.

But Lydia Montgomery and her clique clung to her like glue, leaving no chance to escape.

When she spotted Vincent in the audience, her blood ran cold.

Even worse—

Richard Langley sat right beside her father!

Victoria Langley sipped tea elegantly.

Behind her stood six imposing figures—the Langley brothers.

Sophia's legs trembled, barely supporting her weight.

She bit her lower lip hard to stifle a scream.

"Sophia, look!" Lydia tugged her arm excitedly. "Your whole family came!"

"This ceremony must be for you!"

"How enviable..."

The sycophantic chatter around her stabbed at Sophia's heart like knives.

She stood frozen, struggling to breathe.

Isabella Valentine strode past in stilettos.

Her red lips curled into a mocking smirk as she headed toward the Valentine seating.

"Harvard suddenly holding an awards ceremony?" Oliver Valentine frowned.

Isabella lounged in her seat, amusement glinting in her eyes. "Just wait for the show."

The field gradually filled with attendees.

Countless curious gazes lingered on the Langley family.

Whispers rippled through the crowd:

"Which elite family is that?"

"Are those Sophia Lowell's parents in the middle?"

"Those six gorgeous men behind them must be her brothers. Unbelievable..."
###Chapter 258

Sunlight streamed through the chapel's stained glass, casting a glow on Sophia Lowell's pale face. She stood at the center of the crowd, her fingers unconsciously twisting the hem of her dress.

Evelyn Laurent leaned against the wall, a faint smirk playing on her lips. She idly twirled a strand of hair, but her gaze remained locked on Sophia.

"Word is you're the seventh daughter of the Lowell family?" Evelyn's voice floated over, sharp as a blade.

Sophia's breath hitched.

Dr. Gregory Evans' voice cut through the tension. "Second place in the charity fundraiser—Sophia Lowell from the Physics Department."

The room fell silent.

Sophia felt the weight of countless stares like spotlights. She saw Vincent Lowell's eyes redden with emotion, while Lydia Montgomery frantically signaled at her.

"Sophia, go up there!" Someone nudged her forward.

Her legs felt like lead, each step an agonizing effort. The air in the chapel thickened, making it hard to breathe.

Sophia bit her lower lip hard. She suddenly realized she stood at a crossroads in her life.

One wrong move, and everything would crumble.

She took a deep breath and made her decision.

Under the watchful eyes of the crowd, Sophia walked straight to Richard Langley and Victoria Langley. Her voice was barely a whisper. "Dad. Mom."

Then she turned to the six young men behind them. "Brothers."

Victoria's eyes turned icy.

"Whose daughter is this?" Her voice rang clear and mocking. "My daughter is far more beautiful than you."

Sophia froze as if struck by lightning.

She saw Vincent lurch up from his wheelchair, Lydia covering her mouth in shock. The chapel fell into stunned silence, everyone reeling from the sudden turn of events.

"I—" Sophia opened her mouth, but no sound came out.

Victoria rose gracefully, looking down at her with disdain. "So young, yet already scheming to claim relations? The Langley family doesn't open its doors to just any stray."

Evelyn let out a quiet laugh from the corner.

Sophia's world spun. She finally understood—the carefully woven lie had unraveled completely.
###Chapter 259

Victoria Langley's words pierced through Sophia Lowell's facade like a dagger.

Her fingernails dug into her palms, but she felt no pain.

"You—" Margaret Hill began to retort when Sophia yanked her sleeve.

Victoria curled her lips in disdain. "What's wrong? Scared now?"

A commotion erupted from the audience.

"Impossible!" Nigel Winthrop shot up from his seat, his chair screeching across the floor.

His burning gaze locked onto Sophia, fury blazing in his eyes.

Lydia Montgomery's drink clattered to the ground.

She suddenly remembered Sophia's enigmatic smile whenever the Lowells were mentioned.

"You deceived us all!" someone shouted angrily.

Victoria advanced slowly, her stilettos tapping a menacing rhythm.

"Who gave you the audacity to impersonate a Lowell heiress?"

Vincent Lowell's face turned ashen as he pointed a trembling finger at Sophia. "Do you realize you've endangered the entire family?"

The crowd exploded.

"Those donation records must be fake!"

"Give back my limited-edition bag!"

"Investigate all her financial sources!"

The uproar grew louder. Sophia staggered back two steps.

Her lips parted, but no sound came out.

Victoria smirked and unlocked her phone. "Shall I play your chat logs with those sugar daddies for everyone?"

The final blow landed.

Sophia's legs gave way, and she collapsed onto the stage.

Her carefully constructed lies crumbled to dust in that moment.
###Chapter 260

Sophia Lowell's tears spilled over as her entire body trembled like a leaf in the wind.

She knew she was finished.

Utterly and completely finished.

Those who had once flattered her now rushed to trample her underfoot.

Why?

They were the ones who had insisted she was the seventh daughter of the Lowell family!

"Sophia Lowell, you—!"

Vincent Lowell's fingers shook violently, his voice thick with barely contained fury.

He didn't even dare glance at Richard Langley's expression.

This audacious girl had dared to impersonate the seventh daughter of the Lowell family at Harvard University!

Even worse, she had been exposed in front of the entire faculty, student body, and the Lowell family!

His wheelchair lurched forward as Vincent raised his hand and struck Sophia across the face.

Slap!

The sharp sound of the blow echoed through the auditorium.

Sophia staggered back, a trickle of blood seeping from her lip before she collapsed to the floor in disgrace.

"Apologize now!" Vincent's voice was a low growl of suppressed rage.

His chest ached so fiercely he could barely breathe.

Clutching her cheek, Sophia knelt on the ground, sobbing. "I'm sorry... But I never claimed to be her! They were the ones who assumed it!"

"It's all their fault!"

Lydia Montgomery exploded at those words.

She couldn't accept that she had bet on the wrong horse.

To curry favor with Sophia, she had alienated Isabella Valentine—and now she had offended the Lowells too?

"Sophia, have you no shame?" Lydia's face twisted into a hysterical snarl. "You were the one dropping hints! The penthouse at Symphony Heights, the forged donation records—all you!"

Dr. Gregory Evans added coldly, "The donation records were indeed falsified. Sophia wasn't even the second-highest donor."

Lydia shrieked, "She forged them herself!"

Then her voice cut off abruptly.

As if struck by a horrifying realization, she turned stiffly toward Evelyn Laurent, her voice trembling. "E-Evelyn... That hundred-million donation—was it yours?"

Evelyn stood at the center of the crowd, a cold smile curling her lips. "Yes."

Only two students in the Physics Department shared the surname Laurent.

The answer was undeniable.

Lydia stumbled back, her face ashen. "So... you're the real seventh daughter of the Lowell family?"

"We were all fooled! Ha! Every single one of us—by Sophia!"

Her hysterical laughter broke off as her eyes rolled back, and she collapsed to the floor.

"Call the medics! Someone fainted!"

Chaos erupted in the hall.

But Lydia's words detonated like a bomb among the crowd.

Evelyn Laurent... was the true seventh daughter of the Lowell family?!
###Chapter 261

Sophia Lowell's pupils constricted violently.

She whipped her head toward Evelyn Laurent, her fingers trembling uncontrollably.

Evelyn stood bathed in the spotlight, her icy demeanor a stark contrast to the boisterous crowd. A faint smirk played on her lips, her mocking gaze cutting through Sophia like a knife.

That face—bearing an uncanny resemblance to Victoria Langley—was now unbearably painful to behold.

Sophia's world spun.

"This can't be..." she whispered, nails digging deep into her palms.

All this time, she'd been the fool.

Evelyn had known everything, silently watching her pathetic performance. Those meaningful glances, those loaded silences—they were all taunts!

"Evelyn Laurent!" Sophia's voice cracked with hysteria. "You've been playing me?"

She remembered Evelyn's amused smirk when she'd proudly claimed to be the seventh Langley heiress. Humiliation crashed over her in waves.

Vincent Lowell and his family turned ashen.

Vincent trembled in his wheelchair, lips quivering wordlessly. The adopted daughter they'd cast out was the true Langley princess!

Everything made sense now.

The sudden misfortunes, the mysterious setbacks...

Evelyn strode toward the podium.

Victoria and Richard Langley immediately rose to greet her. The six Langley brothers stood in unison, their gazes warm with affection.

When Evelyn took her place beside Victoria, the audience gasped.

The mother and daughter shared identical poise and features—more convincing than any DNA test.

Lillian Rothschild smiled approvingly. Students who'd opposed Evelyn now paled.

"Enjoying the show, brother?" Isabella Valentine swirled her wine glass.

Oliver Valentine scoffed. "That impostor should've been exposed ages ago."

The room erupted.

"My God! Evelyn is the real heiress!"
"How dare Sophia pretend to be her!"
"No wonder Evelyn never bothered to explain..."

The whispers crashed over Sophia like tidal waves.

She stood frozen, mind blank.

Evelyn calmly displayed her phone. The donation records on screen burned into everyone's retinas.

"These are the authentic records." Her voice was glacial. "Sophia's were forged."
###Chapter 262

"That hundred-million-dollar donation came from me."

Evelyn Laurent's lips curved slightly, her gaze sharp as a blade piercing through Sophia Lowell.

"I've given you too many chances."

Her voice was soft, yet every word struck like a dagger.

Sophia's face turned deathly pale, her nails digging deep into her palms.

She refused to accept this!

How could Evelyn be the seventh daughter of the Lowell family?

How could she possess so much evidence?

"Harvard University does not tolerate academic fraud."

Dr. Gregory Evans announced impassively, "Per the board's decision, Sophia Lowell's exchange student status is revoked. She will be expelled immediately."

Sophia trembled violently, her legs buckling beneath her.

Expelled?

Vincent Lowell's face darkened with rage, his finger shaking as he pointed at Sophia.

"You... you—"

Before he could finish, his eyes rolled back, and he collapsed to the floor.

"This is all your fault, you bitch!"

Brandon Lowell snatched his cane and swung it at Sophia.

"Evelyn is my real sister! You did this!"

The cane struck Sophia with a sickening thud.

"Evelyn! Mommy was wrong!"

Margaret Hill suddenly lunged toward Evelyn, tears streaming down her face.

"I shouldn't have listened to lies and driven you away—"

She reached for Evelyn's pant leg.

"Get away from her!"

Victoria Langley kicked Margaret square in the chest.

"Now you want to claim her as your daughter?"

Her eyes were as sharp as steel.

"Did you think about this when you abandoned her in the countryside ten years ago?"

Victoria's voice rang out sharply, "Guards! Escort this entire family to the police station!"

The crowd gasped.

The usually elegant Mrs. Langley now radiated an unshakable authority.

Ethan Sullivan stood in the corner, a faint smile touching his lips.

His girl was finally letting her brilliance shine.
###Chapter 263

Security guards rushed to the scene.

Brandon Lowell continued screaming hysterically at Evelyn Laurent. "Sister! Sophia Lowell forced me into this!"

Even though he despised her.

Now that he knew she was the true seventh daughter of the Langley family, he had to cling to this lifeline.

What if it worked?

The response didn't come from Evelyn.

Theodore Langley strode forward and delivered a stinging slap across his face.

"How dare you call her 'sister'? Get lost!"

Theodore was seething with rage.

This disgusting creature actually dared to claim kinship with Evelyn.

The audacity!

Brandon and Margaret Hill were dragged away by security, still wailing like banshees.

They only quieted down after being gagged with cloth.

As for Vincent Lowell, the university had already prepared a medical team.

He was immediately loaded into an ambulance and taken away.

Sophia slumped on the stage.

Not far away stood Evelyn and her family.

The sight was enough to drive her mad with envy.

The crowd below was furious.

"Sophia Lowell, get out of Harvard!" The chants rose like waves.

People began throwing objects at her.

Stones and water bottles pelted her body.

"Imposter!"

"Who do you think you are?"

"Leave Harvard now!"

The torrent of insults was relentless.

Evelyn watched coldly.

Sophia had brought this upon herself.

Greed always leads to downfall.

Sophia suddenly lifted her head, her eyes filled with venom. "Evelyn Laurent, you must be loving this, aren't you?"

She had driven Evelyn out of the Langley family.

There was no way Evelyn didn't hate her.

Evelyn smirked disdainfully. "Indeed. Watching you suffer brings me great joy."

"Your acting was laughably pathetic."

Sophia clenched her fists.

Out of the corner of her eye, she spotted Ethan Sullivan standing nearby.

She knew it was over.

But if she was going down, she'd drag Evelyn with her.

"Evelyn."

A twisted smile curled her lips. "Did you know Ethan Sullivan is actually..."
###Chapter 264

Sophia Lowell's shrill voice echoed across the field.

Her venomous gaze locked onto Ethan Sullivan as a cruel smirk twisted her lips. "You were never the one in his heart."

"Evelyn Laurent, do you really think he loves you?"

"You're just a stand-in!"

Victoria Langley trembled with rage and delivered a sharp slap across Sophia's face.

Crack!

The crisp sound silenced the entire crowd.

Ethan's face drained of color before quickly regaining composure. A flicker of lethal intent flashed in his eyes as his fists clenched at his sides.

Sophia was determined to burn everything down with her.

The six Langley brothers turned their piercing gazes toward Ethan, their eyes sharp as blades.

"Hahaha!" Sophia clutched her cheek, laughing hysterically.

She wanted to see the Langleys humiliated.

She wanted to watch Evelyn suffer.

Why should they have everything while she had nothing?

"Mom, ignore her," Evelyn said softly, gently pulling Victoria's hand away. "A rabid dog will bite anyone."

Her calm gaze swept over Ethan. "You know exactly what kind of man Mr. Sullivan is."

Victoria took a deep breath, forcing her anger down.

Ethan strode forward, his presence icy. "Security."

Two guards immediately seized Sophia.

As she was dragged away, Sophia mouthed a silent phrase at Evelyn.

Evelyn's pupils constricted.

The field fell deathly quiet.

Every ear strained to catch the next words.

This was explosive gossip about the Sullivan Group's CEO!

"Tch." Lillian Rothschild suddenly scoffed, her voice dripping with disdain. "People actually believe Sophia's nonsense?"

She scanned the crowd with mocking amusement. "Taking the ravings of an impostor seriously? How pathetic."

The onlookers exchanged glances, realization dawning.

Right!

How could anyone trust the words of a proven fraud?

Sophia was truly vicious—dragging others down with her even in defeat.
###Chapter 265

Ethan Sullivan secretly exhaled in relief at Lillian Rothschild's words.

Evelyn Laurent's earlier defense had clearly been protecting him.

The Langley family's expressions softened slightly.

Ethan quickly moved to Evelyn's side, addressing Victoria Langley and the others with quiet resignation. "My devotion to Evelyn is absolute."

His tone carried unmistakable sincerity.

He hadn't caught Sophia Lowell's final whisper to Evelyn—deliberately meant for her ears alone.

Evelyn's brow furrowed as she studied Ethan pensively.

Sophia claimed Ethan's heart belonged to her?

How could that be?

Ethan was the sole heir of Vincent Sullivan, former patriarch of the Sullivan dynasty in the capital.

She'd grown up in a coastal city before being sent to the countryside.

Their paths had never crossed.

Though Lillian dismissed Sophia's words as lies, they burned into Evelyn's mind like a brand.

Impossible to ignore.

Still, she quickly composed herself.

She'd find a chance to question Ethan privately.

Her contemplative gaze made Ethan tense.

But she soon looked away.

News of Sophia's expulsion exploded across Harvard's campus forums, becoming prime gossip material.

Evelyn's true identity as the seventh Langley heiress also dominated conversations.

Everyone marveled at Victoria and Richard Langley's exceptional genes.

Their six sons were extraordinary, and Evelyn's talents spoke for themselves.

Admitted to Harvard without standardized testing.

A showstopping dance performance at the Centennial Gala.

Coupled with her striking beauty, she was unanimously crowned campus queen—an idol to countless admirers.

The awards ceremony resumed after the Sophia incident, proceeding without further disruption.

Afterward, Evelyn waved goodbye to Lillian and left with her parents and brothers.

Ethan followed silently.

He felt compelled to explain today's events.

Otherwise...

Unease gnawed at him.

Seated in the passenger seat, Ethan kept his eyes locked on the Langley's car ahead.

Upon arriving at Beverly Hills, he was intercepted by Alexander Langley the moment he stepped out.

Alexander's piercing gaze radiated icy authority. "It's late. We won't entertain guests now."

His controlled tone barely masked the storm beneath.

Ethan's stomach dropped.

Victoria glanced back at him hesitantly before guiding Evelyn inside.

Ethan pressed his lips together. "I wanted—"

"Mr. Sullivan."

Alexander cut him off sharply.

His commanding presence rivaled Ethan's own.

"Leave." The quiet command brooked no argument.
###Chapter 266

Ethan Sullivan's figure disappeared at the end of the hallway.

Alexander Langley stared at the closed elevator doors, his gaze icy cold.

He turned and slammed the front door shut with such force that the vase in the foyer trembled.

The air in the living room instantly turned heavy.

Evelyn Laurent sensed something was wrong. Her eyes darted between her family members.

Her eldest brother had clearly been making excuses to get rid of Ethan.

It was only six in the evening—what did he mean by "it's getting late"?

Suddenly, Sophia's words flashed through her mind, making her heart skip a beat.

Victoria Langley set down her teacup with a sharp clink.

"Evelyn," she said, her voice low. "What exactly is going on between you and Ethan?"

Alexander leaned back on the sofa, his long fingers tapping the armrest.

"The Sullivans have stubbornly refused to break off the engagement all these years. That's suspicious enough." His eyes narrowed. "If he's really got someone else in his heart—"

He didn't finish, but the implication was clear.

Before Evelyn could respond, Victoria sighed.

"I think Ethan does have feelings for someone."

All six brothers shot to their feet, their fists clenched tight.

"He wouldn't dare!" Julian Langley yanked at his tie. "I'll break his legs right now!"

Dominic already had the fruit knife from the coffee table in hand.

"Sit down, all of you!" Victoria smacked the table. "I meant Evelyn!"

The room fell silent.

"Haven't you noticed?" Victoria gave her sons an exasperated look. "All the gifts Ethan's been giving Evelyn lately are tailored to her tastes."

"Shooting range passes, concert tickets—even that limited-edition fountain pen last time."

The tips of Evelyn's ears turned pink.

Alexander scoffed. "That doesn't prove—"

"Prove what?" Victoria cut him off. "Your sister's eyes light up every time she mentions him. Are you blind?"

Evelyn abruptly covered her face with her hands.

The six brothers exchanged glances, their aggressive stance deflating instantly.
###Chapter 267

Victoria Langley crossed her arms, glaring at her six foolish sons with exasperation.

And one foolish daughter.

Evelyn Laurent felt utterly bewildered. The situation was spiraling out of control.

If she was hearing this correctly...

Did Ethan Sullivan actually have feelings for her?

Why else would he dote on her and gift her such expensive presents?

But...

Evelyn couldn't forget Ethan's words.

He was waiting for someone.

The girl who had been kidnapped with him.

He had sworn they would break off their engagement.

Hadn't he loved that girl? Why was it suddenly her?

Evelyn couldn't make sense of it.

Her chest tightened like a stone weighed on her heart.

She lowered her head in silence.

The tension in the living room eased as the six Langley brothers relaxed.

The air remained heavy for a long moment.

Finally, Victoria broke the silence. "Everyone, get some rest. I trust Ethan."

She turned to Evelyn, her gaze softening. "Evelyn, do you love him?"

The question carried gravity.

Though the engagement had lasted years, Victoria had witnessed Ethan's devotion to Evelyn.

But what mattered most was her daughter's heart.

She needed to know if Evelyn truly loved Ethan.

She wanted her to follow her heart and be with someone she genuinely cherished.

Evelyn rarely showed uncertainty, but now she hesitated before whispering, "Mom... I don't know."

Strictly speaking, she had only known Ethan for half a year.

She had only returned to the Langley family six months ago.

Before that, she hadn't even understood familial love—let alone romance.

She couldn't define her feelings for Ethan.

Love?

She didn't even know what love meant. But being with Ethan felt... comfortable.

Victoria wasn't surprised by her answer.

She gently ruffled Evelyn's hair. "You're still young, sweetheart. There's no need to rush. But if Ethan ever hurts you, promise you'll tell me."

Richard Langley added firmly, "Evelyn, always protect yourself."

"Your mother and I would never force you into a marriage you don't want. You're not a pawn for alliances, so don't pressure yourself."

Evelyn's nose stung.

She had feared becoming a sacrificial lamb for the family's interests. After all, arranged marriages were common among elites like the Langleys.

Hadn't Ethan initially kept their engagement to avoid another match?

The thought tangled her emotions further.

But she masked it well, offering a faint smile. "I understand, Dad."

Straightening her posture, she declared with pride, "Don't worry. No one can bully me."

Anyone who tried would learn the meaning of absolute power.
###Chapter 268

Victoria Langley and Richard Langley exchanged a knowing smile as they watched Evelyn Laurent's confident demeanor.

The tense expressions on Alexander Langley and his brothers' faces gradually relaxed.

"Evelyn, promise you'll tell us if anything happens." Alexander ruffled her hair, his voice tender yet firm.

Warmth blossomed in Evelyn's chest.

This was what real family felt like.

They stood in stark contrast to Vincent Lowell's household - always having her back, protecting her unconditionally.

This warmth was slowly melting the ice around her heart.

Her fingers curled into determined fists.

She would hold onto this family with everything she had.

Back in her bedroom, Evelyn's thoughts drifted unbidden to Ethan Sullivan.

What exactly were his feelings for her?

The question kept her tossing and turning.

She strained to recall details of that kidnapping incident, but the memories remained frustratingly elusive.

Meanwhile, in Alexander's room.

The blue glow of his computer screen illuminated his grim expression.

"Find out who Ethan's true love is." His voice turned icy as he issued the command through the phone. "Immediately."

He wouldn't tolerate anyone hurting his sister.

Next door, Victoria's composed mask slipped the moment she closed the door.

"We need to uncover why Ethan hasn't called off the engagement." Her voice held a dangerous edge.

Sophia Lowell's earlier comment had allowed her to catch Ethan's fleeting moment of panic.

Though Ethan's affection for Evelyn seemed genuine, what if...

What if Evelyn was merely a substitute?

Richard embraced his wife gently. "Don't worry too much. Ethan isn't that kind of man."

"He's not an ordinary man." Victoria's eyes turned sharp.

Both knew the blood staining Ethan's hands from claiming the Sullivan family's leadership.

Sleep would elude them tonight.

Evelyn restlessly pondered Ethan in her bed.

Alexander investigated through the night.

His five brothers each pursued their own leads.

Richard deployed his most elite intelligence operatives.

As for Ethan...

Staring at the ceiling, an overwhelming unease gripped him.

All of it traced back to Sophia's fatal words.
###Chapter 269

Ethan Sullivan stood by the floor-to-ceiling window, cigarette ash crumbling from his fingertips.

The image of Sophia Lowell's deceitful face flashed in his mind, his eyes turning glacial.

"Prepare the car."

His voice was icy as he spoke through the intercom.

Thirty minutes later, in the CEO's office of Sullivan Group.

"I want the Lowell Corporation wiped out within three days." Ethan slammed a file onto the desk. "And notify all our partners—anyone who aids the Lowells will be considered an enemy of Sullivan Group."

His assistant broke into a cold sweat. "Understood, Mr. Sullivan."

The hospital room reeked of antiseptic.

Vincent Lowell's eyes snapped open, his chest heaving.

"Father!" Brandon Lowell rushed to the bedside, fury still etched on his face.

A faint sob came from the corner.

Sophia huddled against the wall, her expensive dress in tatters, bruises mottling her exposed skin.

"Where is that bitch?" Vincent rasped.

Brandon yanked Sophia by her hair, dragging her to the bed.

Sophia gasped in pain.

"Look what you've done!" Vincent hurled a glass at her. "You've disgraced the Lowell name!"

Shards sliced her cheek, leaving a trail of blood.

Margaret Hill watched coldly. "We should've left you to rot in that orphanage."

Sophia trembled violently.

A month ago, she'd been the envy of high society—the beloved Lowell heiress.

"I... I didn't mean to..." she choked out.

"Shut up!" Brandon kicked her in the stomach. "If you hadn't impersonated the real Lowell daughter, we wouldn't be ruined!"

Sophia curled into a ball, agony searing through her.

She remembered Evelyn Laurent's mocking gaze.

The true seventh daughter of the Lowells must be laughing at her downfall.

"Now all of Boston knows we raised an imposter." Vincent coughed violently. "Our stocks crashed. Creditors are pounding on our doors!"

The hospital door burst open.

Black-suited bodyguards filed in.

"By Mr. Sullivan's orders, the Lowells are to leave Boston immediately." The lead guard's voice was flat. "Or else..."

His gaze lingered on the trembling Sophia.

Vincent's face turned ashen.

He knew—the Lowells were finished.
###Chapter 270

Sophia Lowell's voice now triggered a conditioned fear response in him.

His body tensed involuntarily every time he heard it.

He braced himself for another earth-shattering revelation.

Sophia wisely pressed her lips together.

Then—

BANG!

The hospital door was kicked open violently.

A dozen men in black filed in wordlessly and immediately began attacking.

"What are you doing? This is a hospital!"

"Help! Security! Where are the guards?"

"Ah! My leg!"

Screams erupted one after another.

The assailants specifically targeted Brandon Lowell and Margaret Hill.

Sophia was already bruised and battered—they feared further blows might kill her.

Ten minutes later.

The four were tossed out of the hospital entrance like garbage.

"Scum like you aren't welcome in Harvard City," the lead enforcer said coldly. "Leave by sundown, or else—"

His knuckles cracked ominously.

The threat was unmistakable.

Vincent Lowell's face darkened with rage, his nails digging into his palms.

Yet he forced an ingratiating smile. "We're leaving right now—right now..."

His legs were useless.

He couldn't afford to lose his life too.

"What are you standing around for?" Vincent snarled at Sophia. "Carry me!"

Gritting her teeth, Sophia bent down with trembling limbs.

The moment she hoisted Vincent onto her back, her vision blurred.

Was this the elite life she'd dreamed of?

Once, Vincent had looked at her with pride.

When she got into Harvard University, the whole family celebrated her.

Now?

She was just a human crutch.

A punching bag.

Sophia bit her lower lip until it bled.

Was all of this really her fault?

If only they'd treated Evelyn Laurent better...

If they hadn't been so shallow...

She crushed the thought before it fully formed.

She would never admit that country girl was superior.

Never.
###Chapter 271

The Lowell family hastily packed their belongings under cover of darkness and fled Capital City in disgrace.

No sooner had they crossed the city limits than three black SUVs surrounded them.

"Well, if it isn't Mr. Lowell," sneered a thickset man stepping from a vehicle, his leather shoes sinking into the muddy road. "Running away like a whipped dog?"

Vincent Lowell trembled so violently his wheelchair nearly overturned.

He recognized the man—loan shark Hugo Maddox.

"M-Mr. Maddox..." Vincent forced a grimace worse than a sob. "What brings you here—"

Hugo kicked the wheelchair, sending it lurching. "Six months I've hunted you! Five million plus interest—settle up today!"

Sophia Lowell cowered behind her mother, only to be yanked forward by two brutes.

"Not bad," Hugo gripped Sophia's chin, forcing her swollen face upward. "Punched-up face but a killer body."

Margaret Hill lunged to protect her daughter—a backhand sent her sprawling.

"Mr. Maddox!" Vincent toppled from his chair. "I'll repay everything! Don't hurt my family!"

Hugo crouched, his cigarette nearly scorching Vincent's cheek. "Begging now?" His grin turned feral. "But I've got a better idea."

A nod sent Sophia being dragged toward a vehicle.

"Harvard grad, right?" Hugo's voice dripped mockery. "My club needs hostesses—she'll work off the debt."

Vincent turned ashen. "No! My daughter can't—"

"Seven million." Hugo held up two fingers. "Pay now or..." His gaze slid to Sophia's struggling form.

Margaret clung to Hugo's leg. "We'll sell our house!"

He kicked her away. "That dump?" A cold laugh. "Won't cover the interest."

Sophia's screams pierced the empty countryside. Vincent collapsed in the mud, helpless as she was shoved into the SUV.

"Dad! Save me!" Her nails left bloody streaks on the door.

Hugo patted Vincent's cheek. "Don't worry—I'll take good 'care' of her." He turned, then paused. "Your wife's aged, but she'll do after a wash."

Vincent shook uncontrollably as Margaret was hauled toward another vehicle. Engines roared—the black SUVs vanished in a spray of dirt.

Only Vincent remained, his elongated shadow stretching across the mud in the dying sunset.
###Chapter 272

Liam Croix took a drag from his cigarette, studying Vincent Lowell and his daughter through narrowed eyes.

He suddenly scoffed. "Harvard's top student? More like a failed exchange student. Vincent, your audacity is astounding."

Smoke curled around his fingers as he held up five digits. "Five million. Plus your daughter. Consider the interest waived."

Vincent's face turned ashen.

"If you can't pay..." Liam's gaze slid to Brandon and Margaret. "Shall we add your wife and son to the collateral?"

He deliberately drew out the last word.

This was a mission from his superiors—to make the Lowells suffer beyond imagination.

A perfect chance to complete his task and curry favor with the big shots.

Two birds with one stone.

"No!"

Sophia Lowell's shrill cry cut through the air.

Her entire body trembled, but she forced her chin up. "Mr. Croix, I can bring you greater value!"

"Vincent and the others are yours to deal with. I severed ties with them long ago!"

Her voice cracked with suppressed sobs.

Liam's predatory stare reminded her of the humiliation Sebastian Royston had inflicted.

That degradation—she'd rather die than endure it again.

"Interesting." Liam arched an eyebrow.

Vincent exploded. "You ungrateful bitch! Denying your own father?"

"Father?" Sophia's laugh was ice.

Her wounds still throbbed beneath her clothes.

Each scar bore their signature.

"Take them away." Liam flicked his wrist.

Bodyguards roughly shoved Vincent into a waiting car.

Margaret and Brandon struggled futilely before being dragged off.

Only Sophia remained on the empty lot.

Liam exhaled a smoke ring. "Explain. How exactly will you make me money?"

She leaned in, whispering against his ear.

A calculating gleam flashed in Liam's eyes. "Fine. We'll do it your way."

His fingers dug into her chin. "Don't disappoint me."

Sophia swallowed her revulsion, nodding obediently. "You have my word, Mr. Croix."

"Back to Cloudhaven!" Liam barked.

This game of cat and mouse had only just begun.
###Chapter 273

Evelyn Laurent quickly pushed thoughts of Vincent Lowell to the back of her mind.

Finals week descended upon Harvard University, casting a tense atmosphere over the entire Physics Department.

Evelyn sat in the library, her notebook sprawled open with formulas scribbled across the pages. Lillian Rothschild chewed on the end of her pen, frowning at the problem set before her.

"Use Fourier transform here," Evelyn tapped the question lightly with her pencil.

A few physics majors nearby glanced at them hesitantly but ultimately kept their distance.

Since Evelyn's true identity had been exposed, those who once mocked her alongside Sophia Lowell now avoided her like the plague. They skirted around her carefully, even their eye contact measured and cautious.

Lydia Montgomery's seat remained empty. After the incident, she rarely showed up to class, and when she did, she seemed lost in a daze.

"Finally done!" Lillian burst out of the exam hall, stretching her arms wide.

Sunlight filtered through the plane trees in front of the academic building, casting dappled shadows. Just as Evelyn was about to speak, she noticed the mischievous glint in Lillian's eyes.

"Your man's here!" Lillian waggled her eyebrows and jerked her chin toward the distance. "I'm out!"

Beside a black Maybach, Ethan Sullivan's tall frame stood out sharply. He leaned against the car door, his gaze burning into Evelyn.

A week apart had honed his jawline even more sharply.

"How was the exam?" Ethan reached for her backpack.

Evelyn sidestepped his hand. "Fine."

The warmth inside the car chased away the chill but did nothing to dissolve the silence between them. Ethan's fingers tightened slightly around the steering wheel.

"You're avoiding me," he said abruptly.

Evelyn stared at the scenery flashing past the window without answering.

"Is it because of what Sophia said?" Ethan's voice was low. "Or... did you find something?"

Evelyn whipped her head around, meeting his deep, unreadable gaze. Emotions she couldn't decipher swirled within them.

"You knew I was looking into you?"

The corner of Ethan's mouth lifted in a bitter smile. "The Lowells pulled strings to check flight records from three days ago. And..." He paused. "The archives of Cloudhaven Orphanage from fifteen years ago."

Evelyn's breath caught.
###Chapter 274

Alexander Langley acted swiftly, kicking Ethan Sullivan out of the "Princess Evelyn Fan Club" group chat.

Ethan stared at his phone screen, fingers trembling slightly.

Evelyn Laurent bit her lower lip. "I don't believe a single word Sophia says."

Yet the phrase "Ethan Sullivan is in love with you" echoed relentlessly in her mind like a curse.

She rubbed her temples in frustration.

Ethan hesitated, then finally murmured, "Shall we get dinner?"

"Sure."

The car started smoothly, heading toward Ethan's favorite private dining spot.

Just outside campus, a black Maybach blocked their path.

Alexander stepped out with long strides, his gaze sharp as a blade.

"Get out," he said, yanking open the passenger door.

Evelyn froze.

Ethan's knuckles whitened as he gripped the steering wheel.

Their eyes locked in a silent battle.

But Alexander turned to Evelyn. "We're going home."

"What happened?"

"An emergency."

Evelyn hesitated, glancing at Ethan before finally exiting the car.

Ethan watched their retreating figures in the rearview mirror and slammed his fist against the wheel.

He dialed a number. "Cancel the reservation."

His carefully planned confession had just been ruined.

At the Langley mansion, Evelyn sensed something was wrong the moment she stepped inside.

Victoria Langley sat rigidly on the sofa, her expression stormy.

"Mom, what's going on?"

Evelyn's gaze landed on the coffee table—and her pupils constricted violently.

Why was that diary here?

Her heart leaped into her throat.
###Chapter 275

Evelyn Laurent quietly moved to the sofa and sat down with caution.

Her head was lowered, fingers unconsciously twisting the hem of her dress.

Victoria Langley's expression softened slightly, but when her gaze landed on the documents on the coffee table, her brows furrowed tightly again. "Evelyn, tell me the truth. What is all this?"

The papers trembled faintly in Victoria's grip.

Evelyn discreetly glanced around the room.

Her father, Alexander Langley, wore a stormy expression. Her five brothers were equally stone-faced.

The atmosphere in the living room was suffocating.

"I—"

Before she could speak, Theodore Langley cut in angrily, "Did that bastard Ethan Sullivan force you to sign this?"

Theodore's fists clenched audibly, his eyes burning with fury.

The agreement spelled it out in black and white: Their relationship was a sham. Once Ethan found the woman he truly wanted to marry, the engagement would be terminated immediately.

Every clause stabbed at the Langley family's hearts.

Ethan had used their treasured daughter as a shield.

Worse, his heart still belonged to the girl who had been kidnapped with him a decade ago.

Victoria's hands shook slightly, her eyes brimming with disappointment.

Evelyn took a deep breath and lifted her chin. "He didn't force me."

Her voice was soft but firm.

"I was the one who wanted to call it off first."

"This is better for both of us."

The room fell deathly silent.

Evelyn bit her lip before continuing, "Mom, Dad, brothers... I don’t want to be tied down by an engagement so soon."

"I know you all like Ethan, but..."

She paused, her gaze clear and resolute. "Right now, marriage isn’t what I want."

It was the first time she had spoken her mind so openly.

Julian Langley was the first to respond. "Evelyn’s right. There’s no need to rush into this."

"I support ending the engagement," Theodore immediately agreed.

The others nodded in unison.

Victoria studied her daughter’s stubborn expression and finally sighed. "As long as you’re happy."

Evelyn’s eyes grew slightly damp. She knew her family would always stand by her.
###Chapter 276

Victoria Langley gazed at her daughter's face, her fingertips lightly brushing through the girl's hair.

"Evelyn, are you absolutely certain about this?"

Evelyn Laurent pressed her lips together and nodded, her eyelashes casting delicate shadows under the light.

"Mother, I refuse to be shackled by this engagement any longer."

A sudden smile curved Victoria's lips, gentle creases appearing at the corners of her eyes.

"Then we'll go to the Sullivans' immediately."

Evelyn's head jerked up, her fingers unconsciously tightening around the hem of her dress.

"Now?"

Ethan Sullivan's stormy expression flashed through her mind, an inexplicable weight settling in her chest.

Victoria observed her daughter's reaction with careful neutrality as she rose gracefully.

"Strike while the iron is hot."

Six brothers materialized around them in perfect synchronization. Alexander Langley seized his sister's wrist decisively.

"Move out!"

Surrounded by her brothers, Evelyn found her steps slowing despite their momentum.

She remembered the rigid line of Ethan's jaw whenever the broken engagement was mentioned.

Recalled all those times he'd quietly shielded her from trouble without a word.

The Langley motorcade descended upon the Sullivan estate in full force.

The butler burst into the drawing room in disarray.

"Sir! The Langleys have arrived in force!"

Vincent Sullivan set down his teacup with deliberate calm, his gaze drifting toward the closed door on the second floor.

"Let the boy stew for a while."

Upstairs, Ethan stood at the window, his knuckles pressed against the chilled glass.

He watched Alexander lead Evelyn from the car, his expression darkening instantly.

Victoria rang the doorbell with aristocratic poise.

"We're here to dissolve the engagement."

Evelyn lingered at the back of the group, her heartbeat stuttering.

Suddenly, she wasn't certain what answer she truly wanted to hear.
###Chapter 277

Steward Zhang had just finished speaking with Vincent Sullivan when Victoria Langley's entourage arrived at the Sullivan mansion with an imposing presence.

"Sir, the Langleys are here," Steward Zhang announced respectfully as he opened the door, but his heart skipped a beat when he saw their expressions.

He silently lit a metaphorical candle for young master Ethan in his mind.

"What a pleasant surprise. To what do we owe this visit?"

Vincent Sullivan greeted them with a warm smile, his gaze sweeping over the Langley family before settling on Evelyn Laurent.

The six Langley brothers stood rigid, their faces stormy with barely contained fury.

Though Victoria and Richard Langley appeared composed, the chilling aura around them was palpable.

Only Evelyn remained unfazed.

Vincent took note of everything.

"We came to speak with Ethan," Victoria said coolly. "Evelyn has something to say to him in person."

"Steward Zhang, fetch my son," Vincent instructed casually. "The boy locked himself in his room earlier—no idea what got into him."

He deliberately paused.

"I've never seen him so distraught before."

As he spoke, Vincent cast a meaningful glance at Evelyn.

Victoria and Richard exchanged a look, understanding dawning.

They took their seats on the sofa, and Victoria cut straight to the point. "Vincent, given our families' longstanding friendship, I'll speak frankly."

She could tell Vincent already knew everything.

And more importantly—

He seemed to be leaving the decision entirely in the Langleys' hands.

Vincent nodded. "Of course."

Upstairs, Ethan Sullivan gripped the woven charm bracelet so tightly his knuckles turned white.

A tempest of emotions raged in his eyes, his entire body taut with restless agitation.

Knock knock knock—

"Young master, the Langleys are here. Your father requests your presence."

Ethan's heart lurched.

Suppressing his unease, he schooled his expression and opened the door.

Downstairs, the Langleys and Vincent sat facing each other, the air thick with tension.

The moment Ethan appeared, his gaze locked onto Evelyn.

Simultaneously, six pairs of icy eyes pinned him in place, their hostility sharp enough to flay him alive.

"Uncle, Aunt, Alexander... Theodore," Ethan greeted each respectfully.

Theodore Langley scoffed. "Don't call me that—you're older than me!"

The address made his skin crawl.

How could this man have such audacity?

"Sit," Victoria said flatly, not even sparing him a glance.

Her demeanor was a far cry from her usual warmth.

Vincent smoothly intervened. "Weren't we here to discuss something?"

Alexander Langley wordlessly slid a document across the table toward Vincent. "Take a look, Mr. Sullivan."

His voice was glacial.

After pushing the file forward, he withdrew his hand, offering no further explanation.

Ethan's temple throbbed as he recognized the contents.

His lips pressed into a thin line, his gaze darkening as it returned to Evelyn.
###Chapter 278

Evelyn Laurent felt the scorching gaze on her. Her fingers curled slightly as she hid the agreement behind her back.

She'd been caught.

Now the entire family would share her humiliation.

Vincent Sullivan's smile froze when his eyes landed on the document.

He whipped his head toward Ethan Sullivan, his glare murderous.

"Ethan Sullivan!"

The coffee table shook as Vincent slammed his palm down. His voice was laced with ice. "You've got nerve. Signing this kind of agreement with Evelyn?"

"If you don't like her, say it outright. Why play these games?"

Ethan kept his eyes lowered, silent.

He knew he was in the wrong.

Vincent's rage boiled over. He grabbed the feather duster beside the table and swung it at Ethan. "I'll beat some sense into you today, you ungrateful brat!"

"Uncle Vincent!"

A slender figure suddenly stepped between them.

Evelyn gripped the feather duster with white-knuckled force.

"I signed the agreement willingly," she said, lifting her chin defiantly. "If you're going to hit him, hit me too."

A flicker of amusement crossed Vincent's eyes, though his expression remained stormy. "Step aside, Evelyn. This boy needs to be taught a lesson!"

He yanked the duster back.

It didn't budge.

He pulled harder.

Still immovable.

Vincent stared.

Since when did this girl have such a grip?

"I was the one who proposed the engagement," Evelyn said softly but clearly. "Neither of us wants a relationship built on obligation."

She felt Ethan's gaze burning into her back.

Her heart twisted.

"So..." She took a deep breath. "Please grant us your blessing to end the engagement."

It was the first time she'd spoken so much in front of an elder.

Her fingertips trembled.

Yet she felt an inexplicable sense of release.

"Uncle Vincent," Alexander Langley interjected coldly, "forced affection never lasts."

He stood, his imposing frame casting a shadow.

"Since Ethan's heart belongs to another, don't waste my sister's time."

This wasn't a request.

It was a declaration.
###Chapter 279

Sunlight streamed through the floor-to-ceiling windows into the Sullivan family's living room. The six Langley brothers formed a protective circle around Evelyn, standing like sentinels.

"Ethan Sullivan has someone else in his heart. Why should our Evelyn suffer this humiliation?" Vincent Langley spoke coldly, his expression stern.

"Exactly!" Sebastian Langley slammed his hand on the table as he stood. "If he wants to marry our sister, he must love her wholeheartedly!"

"The jewel of our family will never marry a man whose heart belongs to another." Julian Langley's voice held finality.

Ethan's knuckles turned white. His Adam's apple bobbed, but no words came out.

How could he explain? Should he just admit the girl who haunted his dreams was Evelyn herself?

Victoria Langley elegantly lifted her teacup and took a sip. "Vincent, we all admire Ethan's loyalty."

"To keep searching for over a decade because of a childhood promise—that kind of devotion is rare."

"So we've decided to grant his wish."

Evelyn's head jerked up, but her mother silenced her with a look.

"Aunt Victoria!" Ethan stood abruptly. "Actually, I—"

"No need." Victoria interrupted gently. "Love can't be forced. Our Evelyn has other options."

She gave Ethan a meaningful glance. "I hope you find that girl soon and understand your own heart."

Ethan froze as if struck by lightning.

Vincent Sullivan cleared his throat. "In that case, let's consider the engagement null and void. Evelyn, what do you think?"

His sharp gaze pinned Evelyn in place.

Her fingers tightened around her skirt. "Thank you for your understanding, Uncle Vincent."

Richard Langley rose to leave. "We've overstayed our welcome."

"Our Ethan was at fault." Vincent Sullivan apologized.

Victoria guided her daughter out, her heels clicking sharply against the marble floor.

Silence descended upon the living room.

Vincent Sullivan gazed thoughtfully at the doorway before turning to see his son's thunderous expression.

"Ethan—"

Before he could finish, Ethan stormed upstairs, slamming his bedroom door with enough force to shake the house.

Vincent shook his head and retreated to his own room.

The moment the door closed, he burst into laughter.

His always composed son had finally shown his true colors.
###Chapter 280

The night was ink-black. Ethan Sullivan stood by the window, his fingers unconsciously tracing the faded woven charm bracelet.

Ten years.

The bracelet had long lost its original vibrancy, much like the blurred figure in his memories.

"Young master, your father requests your presence," murmured Mr. Zhang outside the door.

Ethan placed the bracelet back into its velvet box, his expression unreadable.

Vincent Sullivan was brewing tea in the study.

"I hear the Langleys are sending Evelyn abroad?" Vincent asked without looking up.

Ethan's posture stiffened.

"You already knew."

It wasn't a question.

Vincent finally raised his eyes to his son's tense jawline. "The Langleys are giving you time."

The teacup clinked against the saucer.

"After ten years of searching, you're certain it's her?"

Ethan's fists clenched.

Of course he was certain.

Those eyes—he could never mistake them.

Yet the words died on his lips.

Vincent sighed. "Go to the Langleys. Don't live with regrets."

The black sports car shot through the gates like an arrow.

The Langley mansion blazed with light.

Victoria Langley stood at the second-floor window, watching the familiar car vanish into darkness.

"Is this too cruel?" she whispered.

Richard Langley embraced his wife from behind. "If he can't pass this test, he doesn't deserve our daughter."

Victoria recalled the investigation report.

That kidnapping a decade ago had altered both children's fates.

Her Evelyn had suffered so much abroad.

While Ethan had spent ten years searching, clinging to a promise.

"But what if—" Victoria hesitated.

"No what-ifs," Richard said firmly. "If he can't distinguish obsession from love, he has no place by Evelyn's side."

Upstairs, Evelyn Langley sat at the piano.

The keys responded dully beneath her fingers.

She remembered her parents' words earlier.

"Evelyn, you'll be studying in France."

It wasn't a suggestion, but a decree.

The music stopped abruptly.

An engine roared outside.

Evelyn moved to the window just as the familiar sports car pulled up to the Sullivan residence.

Her fingers tightened on the curtains.

Ten years.

She should have known—some bonds weren't meant to be.
###Chapter 281

Victoria Langley saw everything with perfect clarity.

She had watched Ethan Sullivan grow up. His character was an open book to her.

Yet it was precisely this familiarity that forced her to take drastic measures.

Her precious daughter had suffered enough.

Evelyn Laurent had endured seventeen years of hardship.

Victoria sighed at the thought.

"Our Evelyn is utterly clueless about matters of the heart," she murmured. "Consider this a chance for Ethan—and for Evelyn to discover what he truly means to her."

She suddenly looked up, unease flickering in her eyes. "Darling, do you think they'll resent me when they realize I orchestrated this?"

Richard Langley stroked her hair tenderly. "Never. Your intentions are pure."

"You always take my side," Victoria huffed playfully.

"My queen's word is law," Richard chuckled, pressing a kiss to her forehead.

A blush crept up her cheeks as she lightly punched his chest. "They're perfect for each other. Since Evelyn won't see it, we're giving them a nudge."

"Your wish is my command."

Evelyn remained oblivious to her parents' scheming.

Lying in bed, she stared at the pink diamond bracelet on her wrist. Its soft glow under the lamplight made her vision blur.

Ethan's face materialized before her.

Sophia's words echoed in her mind—Ethan's unrequited love was for her.

A strange warmth unfurled in her chest.

What had she done all those years ago to leave such an impression? Why had he remained silent during the Sullivan family's interrogation?

Would things have been different if he'd spoken up?

Evelyn shook her head violently. The engagement was over. She should be relieved.

She switched off the main light, leaving only the dim bedside lamp. Curling under the covers, she closed her eyes.

The nightmare struck without warning.

Dank basement air assaulted her senses—mold and blood intermingling. The fleeting image made her fists clench the sheets.

Darkness surged like a tidal wave. Fear morphed into a monstrous presence advancing relentlessly. She twisted restlessly, brows furrowed.

The scene shifted abruptly.

She was running through pitch-black nothingness. Malevolent laughter chased her. Footsteps grew louder.

"You little bitch! Keep running!"

"Leading an escape? I'll kill you!"

A meaty hand yanked her small body upward.

"Let me go!"

Young Evelyn drove her fist into the man's eye. As he recoiled, she scrambled free and kept running.

"I'll slaughter you today!"

The threats pursued her like shadows.
###Chapter 282

Evelyn Laurent caught a glimpse of the man bending down to pick up a thick wooden stick.

He was sprinting toward her.

She hadn't eaten in two days.

Her legs felt like lead, every step sinking into cotton.

Just as the stick was about to strike her back—

A slender figure suddenly rushed from the side and yanked her away.

The boy turned and took the full force of the blow on his back.

"Ugh!"

A pained grunt exploded in her ear.

The strikes rained down.

But he shielded her with his body, his voice trembling yet firm. "Don't be afraid. I'll protect you."

Exhausted, the man dragged them back to the basement, cursing under his breath.

The boy was beaten to the brink of death.

Little Evelyn crawled over, tears dripping. "Does it hurt, big brother?"

He forced a weak smile. "No. I promise I'll get you out of here, Evelyn."

"There are too many of them. We need a plan..."

Two small figures huddled in the dark corner.

In that lightless dungeon, they were each other's only solace.

Evelyn's eyes snapped open.

She stared blankly at the ceiling.

That wasn't a dream.

It was a real memory she had forgotten.

The phantom pain of the beating still lingered on her back.

But only fragments of the memory had resurfaced.

What had happened after the kidnapping?

She strained to remember, but it was like peering through frosted glass.

Only the boy's face remained vivid—piercingly clear.

Ethan Sullivan.

Ten years ago, he had already shielded her from the storm.

That promise—"I'll protect you"—had been made a decade ago.

Her fingers clenched the sheets, knuckles turning white.

Dawn light crept through the window.

Sleep was impossible now.

She dressed quietly in workout clothes.

A morning run might calm her chaotic thoughts.

As soon as she stepped out of the Lowell mansion, she froze.

A man in black sat motionless on a bench in the cold winter morning.

Evelyn frowned.

She steadied her breathing and continued jogging.

The sound of her footsteps made the man turn his head slowly.
###Chapter 283

Evelyn Laurent's footsteps came to an abrupt halt.

The figure on the bench looked especially frail in the morning mist.

Ethan Sullivan sat there, a cigarette burning down to its filter between his fingers.

He resembled a statue dusted with frost, his lashes coated in a thin icy layer.

Evelyn's gaze dropped to the scattered cigarette butts at his feet.

They lay in chaotic heaps, like some silent struggle made tangible.

"Ethan?" she called softly.

The man jolted as if electrocuted.

He moved too quickly, nearly tripping over his own stiff legs.

"I wasn't smoking!" He frantically tossed the cigarette into a trash bin. "Just... lighting it for fun—"

His voice trembled noticeably.

Only then did Evelyn notice his fingers had turned purple from cold.

She frowned. "How long have you been sitting here?"

Ethan avoided her eyes. "Don't remember."

He truly didn't.

After returning from the racetrack, he'd somehow ended up here.

Watching the sky lighten by degrees.

"Couldn't sleep?" Evelyn asked suddenly.

Ethan blinked, then gave a bitter smile. "That obvious?"

In the dawn light, his features looked unusually sharp.

Evelyn turned away abruptly. "Want to go for a run?"

Ethan froze.

He glanced down at his stiff fingers, then up at Evelyn already jogging ahead.

"Wait for me."

He rubbed his face vigorously, bouncing in place a few times.

When Evelyn looked back, she caught him flailing like an awkward penguin.

A laugh escaped her.

The sound made Ethan pause mid-stretch.

Her eyes glittered startlingly bright in the mist.

"What's so funny?" He feigned sternness.

"Nothing." Evelyn resumed running. "Just never thought Mr. Sullivan could be... cute."

When Ethan caught up, he deliberately positioned himself upwind.

He didn't want her smelling the tobacco on him.

They ran side by side through the empty streets, their breaths mingling in white puffs.

Neither mentioned the unsmoked cigarettes.

Or the sleepless night.
###Chapter 284

Liam's gaze locked onto the bouquet in the boy's hand.

The innocent-looking flowers set off alarm bells in his mind.

The child's grip was too precise—a telltale sign of professional assassin training.

"Get back!"

He moved like lightning, shielding Evelyn with his body.

His fingers clamped around the boy's wrist like steel jaws.

"Big brother, what's wrong?" The child's angelic face twisted with a flicker of malice.

Liam twisted his wrist sharply. A cry of pain escaped the boy's lips.

Crushed petals rained from the child's palm—just ordinary flowers.

But that earlier thrust had carried lethal intent.

"Liam!" Evelyn gasped at his sudden movement.

While attention was diverted, the cowering security guard sprang into action.

A silenced pistol flashed toward Liam's back.

The trigger pulled without hesitation.

Phut

The bullet tore through air—only to meet flesh.

A spray of crimson bloomed across Lillian's ivory gown like winter roses.

"Lillian!"

Liam's roar shattered the night.

He caught her collapsing form. Warm blood soaked through his fingers.

The bullet had lodged in her lower back, pumping life onto the pavement.

The guard raised his weapon again.

Liam's eyes turned glacial.

With Lillian in his arms, he blurred forward.

A single kick sent the guard crashing into a stone pillar.

Spine protruding through flesh. Instant death.

Evelyn screamed again.

The wiry boy had produced a combat knife, thrusting toward her heart.

Tires screeched.

A black Lincoln plowed into the child, sending him flying.

Felix leapt from the driver's seat, face ashen. "Everyone okay?"

"Open up!" Liam barreled into the backseat with Lillian.

He tore away bloodied fabric, flushing the wound with water.

One palm struck her abdomen.

Ping—the bullet ricocheted off leather upholstery.

Silver needles flashed. The bleeding slowed.

"Revival Hall. Now!" Liam's voice shook.

Felix floored the accelerator.

Sirens wailed from all directions.

Spotlights flooded the interior. A dozen police officers advanced with drawn weapons.

"Exit the vehicle! Hands on your heads!" A hawk-nosed lieutenant barked through a megaphone.

Liam patted his pockets—his military ID was back at the clinic.

He stepped out, hands raised. "Critical patient inside. Immediate medical attention required."

"Drop your weapons! Now!"

Liam's eyes turned arctic. "Final warning. Move."

"Just shoot him, Captain," an officer muttered.

Before the words faded, Liam materialized beside the speaker.

One hand lifted the lieutenant by the throat.

"Try and stop me."

The roar carried bone-shaking force. Officers clutched their ears in pain.

The suspended lieutenant kicked weakly, face purpling.

Under moonlight, Liam stood like a wrathful deity.

To save Lillian, he'd wage war against the world itself.
###Chapter 285

Ethan Sullivan's eyes darkened abruptly.

An indescribable emotion churned in his chest.

An uncontrollable thought surfaced in his mind.

The token necklace symbolizing their promise had first appeared on Sophia Lowell.

When he first saw Sophia wearing that necklace, he instinctively rejected the truth.

He dismissed the possibility almost instantly.

Yet the necklace hung around Sophia's neck.

What if the girl from back then was really Sophia?

Ethan's brow furrowed deeper.

A cruel realization struck him.

No matter who that girl had been, he wouldn't have fallen for her.

He might have offered generous compensation, but never marriage.

Once, he believed finding that girl meant he must marry her.

But when it wasn't Evelyn Laurent—

Ethan suddenly understood he felt no impulse to wed.

In other words—

He had fallen for Evelyn through their shared moments.

Before knowing she was that girl, he'd already regarded her differently.

At first, it might have been an act.

But later, Ethan knew with certainty—it was no longer pretend.

This realization darkened his gaze further.

"Ethan."

Evelyn's soft voice called to him.

She studied his tense profile. "How did you confirm it was me you sought?"

The corner of Ethan's mouth lifted as he masked the turbulence in his eyes. "The butterfly birthmark behind your left ear."

Evelyn's fingers flew to the spot in surprise. "You remembered after ten years?"

His voice lowered. "And the token."

"Token?"

After a pause, Ethan withdrew two items from his pocket.

One was his necklace. The other—a faded woven charm bracelet with a tiny longevity locket.

He opened his palm slowly.

Evelyn stared at the bracelet as memories flooded back.

Her trembling fingers closed around it.

The buried past sharpened into focus.

It was the eve of the Dragon Boat Festival.

Margaret Hill had unusually taken her shopping.

The crowded mall dazzled young Evelyn with colorful stalls.

Though starved for maternal affection, she still craved attention.

When she paused at a charm bracelet stand, Margaret actually bought one—

An ordinary woven bracelet with a golden longevity locket.

Delighted, Evelyn fastened it around her wrist.

Her mother's first gift.

That day, Margaret didn't just buy the bracelet—

She also bought Evelyn ice cream.
###Chapter 286

Evelyn Laurent cradled the tiny ice cream cone, tentatively licking the melting treat. The cloying cream dissolved on her tongue, but couldn't warm the chill in her heart.

Margaret Hill had promised to buy her a new dress before leaving, instructing the six-year-old to wait obediently at the alley's mouth. Evelyn clutched the half-melted dessert until twilight swallowed the streets.

The chloroform's pungent scent assaulted her senses before she could even cry out "Mommy."

Her lashes fluttered now as fingertips absently traced the faded woven charm bracelet. The locket's engravings had blurred with time, much like that deliberately forgotten summer in her memory.

The kidnapping had been an orchestrated abandonment from the very beginning.

"Evelyn?"

Ethan Sullivan's palm enveloped her icy fingers, warm and steady. He saw the storm clouds swirling in her eyes, dark as the sea before a tempest.

"Just old memories." She returned the bracelet to its velvet case, the metallic whisper against silk unnaturally loud. "Like how this token came into my possession."

Dead leaves skittered from the alley's locust tree, triggering the memory of her fifth day in captivity—the kidnappers' frantic arguing. The Lowells had never intended to pay the ransom.

Ethan suddenly turned her shoulders toward him. "Don't." His thumb brushed moisture she hadn't realized escaped her eyes. "Those monsters belong in hell."

A startled laugh escaped her. The winter wind scattered her hair, revealing the pale scar along her neck—a souvenir from the barbed wire during her escape.

"Is your car warm?" She changed subjects, spotting the Paxil box peeking from his trench coat. The antidepressant was painfully familiar.

Ethan fumbled to conceal it, only to freeze at her quiet confession: "I'm on Zoloft too."

Two fractured souls stood beneath the streetlamp, their shadows merging into something whole. The woven bracelet gleamed dully in the moonlight—a timeworn witness to their shared scars.
###Chapter 287

The icy wind howled as Evelyn Laurent tightened her down jacket around herself. After a moment's hesitation, she slipped into Ethan Sullivan's car.

Warm air rushed over her, thawing her frozen fingers at last.

"How long have you been waiting here?" She couldn't help asking, noticing the redness on the tip of Ethan's nose.

Condensation blurred the view outside the window, but couldn't hide the exhaustion in Ethan's eyes.

His fingers paused slightly on the steering wheel. "Not long."

Evelyn spotted the whitened frostbite marks on his knuckles. Her heart clenched inexplicably.

"About yesterday..." She bit her lower lip. "My parents went too far."

The air inside the car turned heavy.

Ethan gave a bitter chuckle, his long fingers tapping the steering wheel absently. "They were right. I'm not good enough for you."

His words stabbed Evelyn's heart like a thorn.

She jerked her head up, meeting Ethan's deep gaze. "That's not true," she protested instinctively. "It's me—"

BANG!

The window rattled violently from a sudden impact.

Evelyn jumped, turning to see Theodore Langley's handsome face pressed against the glass.

"Evelyn!" Theodore yanked open the back door, teeth clenched. "Sneaking around with some man in the middle of the night?"

Ethan stepped out calmly, standing at attention. "Sixth Brother."

"Who's your brother?" Theodore bristled. "Don't you dare claim relation, old man!"

Evelyn cringed with embarrassment, grabbing her furious brother's arm. "We just ran into each other—"

"Ran into each other?" Theodore scoffed. "His car's been parked outside our building for an hour!"

Evelyn gaped at Ethan in surprise.

Under the moonlight, the man's ears turned pink, yet he remained standing tall and straight like a silent pine tree.
###Chapter 288

Ethan sat with his head lowered, long fingers absently tracing the steering wheel.

Streetlight shadows fell across his lashes, casting his entire figure in unspoken melancholy.

Theodore frowned.

Why did this bastard look like an abandoned golden retriever?

"Evelyn!" Theodore rushed to the car in three strides, yanking the door open. "Why are you with this scumbag? Did he trick you?"

His sharp gaze darted between them before settling on Ethan with open hostility.

"We've called off the engagement, Mr. Sullivan." Theodore's jaw clenched. "Stay away from my sister."

Ethan slowly lifted his head.

"I just didn't want her to be cold." His voice was barely audible. "The car has heating."

Theodore scoffed. "Then why not take her home?"

"The Lowells won't let me through the gates." A bitter smile touched Ethan's lips. "My father barred me from returning too."

Theodore arched an eyebrow. "Vincent kicked you out?"

"Yes." Ethan nodded. "He said I deserved it for losing his daughter-in-law."

Theodore's mouth twitched.

Was this bastard playing the victim card?

"You own other properties."

"Transferred them all to Evelyn." Ethan's expression remained neutral.

Theodore momentarily lost his words.

He shielded Evelyn behind him like a bristling cat. "Stay away from my sister!"

Warmth flooded Evelyn's chest at her brother's protective stance.

She gently tugged Theodore's sleeve. "Sixth Brother, he didn't hurt me."

"You're defending him?" Theodore's eyes widened. "He's the bastard who broke your engagement for another woman!"

Evelyn bit her lip. "Actually... I was the one he'd been waiting for."

"What?!" Theodore whirled around. "Ethan was looking for you?"

His furious gaze swung between them before exploding. "Ethan Sullivan! Why didn't you say so? We could've found Evelyn sooner!"

Ethan's fingers tightened imperceptibly.

He lowered his lashes, voice rough. "I feared... it would endanger her."

The streetlight painted fractured shadows across his profile, isolating him in the glow.
###Chapter 289

Ethan's Adam's apple bobbed as he swallowed his words.

He stared at Theodore's icy expression before sighing. "Theo, I truly didn't know Evelyn was her."

"Even when we brought her back to the Sullivan estate, I had no idea she was the one I'd been searching for."

His voice dropped low with remorse.

He wished he could travel back in time and strangle his past self for signing those documents.

Had he known Evelyn Laurent was that little girl, he'd never have agreed to break off their engagement.

Now the decision felt like shooting himself in the foot.

Theodore snorted. "Idiot."

His cutting remark held no mercy. "Ten years of searching and you still couldn't recognize her? Some love that is."

"Let's go, Evelyn. Don't waste time on this fool."

Theodore grabbed Evelyn's arm to leave.

She glanced back at Ethan's motionless figure.

The tall man looked heartbreakingly lonely in the morning light. Her heart softened. "Would you... like to join us for breakfast?"

Ethan's eyes instantly brightened.

He practically sprinted after them, terrified Theodore might change his mind. "Yes!"

Theodore rolled his eyes dramatically.

But seeing Ethan's pitiful expression reminded him how the man had always looked out for him since childhood.

Plus, Theodore knew Ethan's heart belonged solely to his sister. His anger cooled slightly.

"Only because you got kicked out," Theodore lifted his chin haughtily. "But if you try anything funny, my brothers won't go easy on you."

Ethan grinned like a cat who got the cream. "Whatever you say, Theo."

Theodore made a face but didn't protest further.

As they entered the living room, Alexander looked up from his newspaper.

His expression darkened immediately upon spotting Ethan. "Who invited you?"

"Evelyn did," Ethan answered sweetly, unable to hide his smugness.

Alexander's razor-sharp gaze shifted to Theodore.

"Big bro!" Theodore raised his hands in surrender. "She really invited him herself! I couldn't stop her!"

Bringing home the man whose engagement she'd just broken yesterday?

Theodore wanted to cry. He shot desperate looks at his sister.

Evelyn stifled a laugh. "Alexander, Mr. Sullivan kicked him out. He looked so pitiful..."

Ethan nodded eagerly, giving Alexander his best puppy-dog eyes.

Alexander's eyes narrowed dangerously, the air around him turning frigid. But ultimately, he said nothing more.
###Chapter 290

Alexander Langley's gaze lingered on Evelyn Laurent for a moment before flickering with resignation.

His foolish little sister was being played like a fiddle by Ethan Sullivan.

Long fingers tapped rhythmically against the armrest as he returned his attention to the financial newspaper.

Theodore Langley exhaled quietly, his dress shirt clinging to his damp back.

Even as the company CEO preparing to enter the professional league circuit, he still felt like a chastened child under his eldest brother's scrutiny.

Ethan finally allowed his tense shoulders to relax slightly.

Getting past the Langley estate's front gates meant he'd already won half the battle.

Sebastian Langley froze mid-step on the spiral staircase.

"What are you doing here?" His voice could have flash-frozen the Mediterranean as his eyes narrowed dangerously.

Ethan remained unflappable. "Evelyn invited me."

Sebastian's razor-sharp glare sliced between them before he snorted and took a seat opposite.

As the other Langley brothers descended, the living room's temperature plummeted.

Six pairs of eyes honed to dagger-points impaled Ethan where he sat.

If stares could kill, he'd be leaking from more holes than a colander.

Ethan serenely lifted his teacup, utterly unfazed by the palpable hostility.

"Why so quiet down here?" Victoria Langley's sleep-roughened voice floated from upstairs.

She descended rubbing her eyes, then arched an eyebrow at the unexpected guest. "Ethan?"

He rose immediately with perfect decorum. "Mr. and Mrs. Langley."

Theodore barely suppressed an eye roll.

Such a damn performance.

Richard Langley frowned. "To what do we owe this visit?"

"Father disowned me." Ethan's expression didn't flicker. "Evelyn took me in."

A glimmer of amusement flashed through Victoria's eyes before vanishing.

Richard studied him with new interest.

As if the Sullivan patriarch would ever cast out his only heir.

When his gaze shifted to his daughter, Evelyn threw up both hands. "I really did invite him!"

Her cheeks flushed scarlet, desperate to prevent any misunderstanding.

The atmosphere thickened like overcooked pudding.
###Chapter 291

A glint of amusement flickered in Richard Langley's eyes.

He maintained his aloof expression. "Let's eat."

His slender fingers encircled Victoria Langley's wrist as he guided her downstairs.

Evelyn Laurent rose from her seat just as Ethan Sullivan instinctively moved to her side.

Six pairs of burning eyes seemed to scorch his back.

The corner of Ethan's lips curved slightly.

With Evelyn present, the Langley brothers had no choice but to suppress their displeasure.

At the very least, this breakfast was his to enjoy.

The clinking of silverware filled the dining room.

Evelyn methodically sliced her bacon, catching the dark expressions of the Langley brothers from the corner of her eye.

Alexander Langley abruptly set down his napkin.

"Mr. Sullivan must have pressing matters at the office. Perhaps you should leave early?"

The dismissal couldn't have been more blunt.

Evelyn rose gracefully, the sharp crease of his suit pants unyielding.

"You're right. I should go." He turned to Evelyn. "I'll be staying at the company for a while."

Evelyn frowned. "Why?"

"The old man's orders." A wry smile touched his lips. "I'm forbidden from setting foot in the Sullivan mansion until I've earned your forgiveness."

Theodore Langley scoffed. "Then it seems you'll be sleeping on the streets, Mr. Sullivan."

Evelyn merely shrugged.

His retreating figure carried a hint of solitude.

Evelyn stared at the space he'd occupied, lost in thought.

Had Uncle Sullivan really banished his own son?

No wonder Ethan had only signed the agreement without breaking off the engagement...

"Evelyn!"

Six voices chimed in unison.

Sebastian Langley gripped her shoulders. "Stop thinking about that bastard!"

"Have you forgotten he's in love with someone else?"

Dizzy from the shaking, Evelyn's mind flashed to the desolation in Ethan's eyes moments ago.

Something in her chest gave a faint, inexplicable tug.
###Chapter 292

"What kind of man do you like, Evelyn? I know plenty of eligible bachelors who'd be perfect for you!" Julian Langley winked playfully.

"Ethan Sullivan isn't your only option!"

Her six brothers crowded around Evelyn Laurent, each offering enthusiastic matchmaking suggestions.

Tilting her head thoughtfully, Evelyn countered, "But honestly, can anyone in the country compare to Ethan?"

The brothers fell silent.

Damn.

They couldn't refute their sister's logic.

Julian cleared his throat first. "But Ethan's heart belongs to someone else!"

Evelyn blinked her large eyes earnestly. "The person he's been waiting ten years for... is actually me."

Except for Julian and Theodore, the other four brothers gaped in shock.

This revelation hadn't surfaced in their investigations.

Yet seeing their sister's unwavering confidence, understanding dawned on them.

Their gazes snapped toward their parents.

Victoria Langley simply smiled and nodded.

So Mother had known all along!

Julian's mind raced. "Even if it's you, he only knew you as a child. What if it's just gratitude or guilt?"

"That's not real love. Don't let him deceive you!"

Evelyn frowned at her third brother. "I know that. We've remained friends since calling off the engagement."

The brothers exchanged uneasy glances.

They feared their sister was getting too attached.

That Ethan was a master manipulator!

He'd probably come to the Langley estate just to play the victim.

Their jaws clenched in frustration.

They needed to introduce Evelyn to other exceptional men—immediately.

Julian's eyes sparkled with sudden inspiration. "Evelyn, could you do me a favor?"

Leaning closer, he deployed his Oscar-winning charm with a pout. "Would you join me for a family reality show episode? Just like the one Theodore did with me last time."

"Theodore can't make the next recording. Will you be my partner instead?"

Faced with her movie-star brother's puppy-dog eyes and pleading tone, Evelyn's resistance crumbled.

She glanced at Theodore. "You're really unavailable?"

Theodore caught Julian's subtle headshake and sighed. "Yeah, I have intensive training."

Julian turned up the charm. "Please, little sister? It's just a lighthearted show about sibling dynamics with some fun games."

"If you don't come, they'll pair me with a fake sister." His voice softened. "You're my only real sister."

Evelyn's resolve melted. "Alright, I'll do it."

Then hesitation flickered across her face. "But I've never been on camera before. Won't I embarrass you?"

Her brother was a national treasure.

Could an ordinary girl like her really measure up?
###Chapter 293

Evelyn Laurent finally nodded in agreement to Julian Langley's reality show proposal.

Julian's peach-blossom eyes instantly sparkled with delight. He ruffled Evelyn's hair, unable to suppress his excitement. "I knew you'd say yes, Evie!"

Sunlight streamed through the floor-to-ceiling windows, gilding his features. His face—often called "the nation's first love"—beamed so brightly it seemed to sweeten the air around them.

Evelyn held her breath.

Her third brother truly deserved his title as an Oscar-winning actor.
