Dusting wood chips off her hands, she nodded in satisfaction.

"Done."
###Chapter 387

The last golden rays of sunset vanished beneath the ocean's edge.

The clouds darkened into crimson streaks across the horizon.

Their plan to build a cabin had to be postponed—one day wasn't nearly enough.

Evelyn Laurent efficiently packed down the foundation before gathering vines to weave sleeping mats.

She knew Julian Langley and Ethan Sullivan too well.

These pampered young masters would never tolerate sleeping on hard ground.

As for herself? Any sturdy tree would do for the night.

The single sleeping bag naturally went to Bianca Fairchild, who was still injured.

Ethan walked silently toward the shore.

He couldn't bring himself to handle the still-twitching rabbits.

Seawater lapped at his ankles as he retrieved the fish traps Evelyn had set earlier.

Inside shimmered a few silvery fish and several feisty crabs.

Frowning at the meager haul, he grabbed a spear and dove beneath the waves.

Evelyn had exerted herself too much today—she needed proper nourishment.

Julian attempted to help with the weaving but only slowed progress.

With a resigned sigh, he went to assist Ethan instead.

Bianca's nimble fingers worked swiftly through the vines, creating neat, uniform patterns.

By full nightfall, three thick, cushioned mats lay completed.

The rich aroma of fish stew drifted through the air.

Evelyn's stomach growled traitorously.

Ethan stirred the creamy broth in a stone pot, emerald wild herbs floating atop.

"Try it," he said, handing her a brimming bowl.

Steam curled between them, glistening on his lashes.

The first sip exploded across her tongue—savory, perfectly balanced.

"Delicious," she murmured, eyes closing in pleasure as she drained the bowl.

Ethan wordlessly took the empty vessel and replaced it with another full of flaky, boneless fish.

Evelyn blinked, warmth blooming in her chest.

She ate quietly, missing how Ethan drank from the same bowl her lips had touched.

Julian's jaw clenched.

He opened his mouth to protest when Bianca's sharp glance silenced him.

Darkness fully embraced the island.

Cameramen began packing equipment.

Timothy Gold's amplified voice announced, "That's a wrap for today's live stream!"

The virtual audience erupted in dismay, demanding more footage.

Among all participants, only Evelyn's group had constructed proper shelter.

Rachel and Leo Clemenson, along with Hugo and Crystal Rothschild, received compensation packages after failing to pair up properly.

Hugo stood rigid outside his tent, moonlight stretching his shadow long and thin.

Sea breeze rustled through palm fronds.

Gazing at the star-strewn sky, Evelyn found herself... enjoying this unexpected night.
###Chapter 388

Moonlight spilled like liquid silver over the tranquil island.

The four groups of guests settled in for their first night in the wilderness.

Beatrice Quincy tossed and turned inside her flimsy tent.

Something kept crawling over her sleeping bag.

"Damn this show!" She gritted her teeth and rolled onto her side. The hard ground dug into her bones.

The thin grass mat did nothing to cushion the unyielding earth.

Regret gnawed at her for signing up.

With her phone confiscated, she had no distractions to pass the time.

"Should've told my agent to reject this gig..." She muttered before resigning herself to sleep.

Meanwhile, Evelyn Laurent's group slept soundly.

Julian Langley sighed contentedly on his plush grass bedding.

"Evie, you're a genius." He marveled. "This beats sleeping on rocks any day."

Evelyn chuckled softly. "Get some rest, Julian. Dawn comes early."

Ethan Sullivan leaned against the tent entrance, watching the siblings with quiet amusement.

He thanked his stars Evelyn had accompanied Julian.

If Theodore Langley—the kitchen disaster—had come instead, they'd still be struggling to start a fire.

Not to mention that luxury yacht incident...

A smirk tugged at Ethan's lips.

Night deepened.

Salty sea breezes whispered through the camp.

All four sites had fallen silent.

Then—

"Help! Someone help!"

A bloodcurdling scream shattered the night.

Julian bolted upright, pale as chalk. "Snake? Where?"

Ethan already had the tent flap open. "Rachel and Leo's site."

Moonlight revealed Rachel Clemenson stumbling out in tears.

"A snake—inside our tent!" Her voice trembled.

Leo Clemenson hopped around like a madman. "Production! Get over here!"

Chaos erupted.

Other guests scrambled to inspect their own tents.

Beatrice fled the campsite entirely, frozen in terror on open ground.

Crew members arrived in a flurry of flashlight beams.

"What happened?" The director demanded.

Rachel pointed a shaking finger. "In there...a black snake..."

Staff approached cautiously.

A dark shape darted out.

Gasps erupted.

The flashlight beam chased the fleeing creature—

A terrified iguana.

The director exhaled. "Just a local lizard. Harmless."

Rachel collapsed sobbing.

No one would sleep tonight.
###Chapter 389

Rachel Clemenson's face was deathly pale.

Tears streaked her cheeks as she stumbled out of the tent.

Leo Clemenson followed close behind, losing a shoe in his haste.

The siblings fled in disarray. Rachel tripped over a tree root, slamming her knees against the ground.

She barely registered the pain as she scrambled up and kept running.

"Snake! Help!"

Her shrill scream pierced the night, jolting the entire campsite awake.

Crew members rushed over with tools in hand. Other guests peeked out from their tents.

Evelyn Laurent sat up languidly, a mocking glint in her eyes.

She adjusted her sleeping bag, making no move to rise.

Inside the tent, Timothy Gold froze, flashlight in hand.

A thumb-sized snake slithered lazily across the ground, flinching at the sudden light.

"Seriously?"

He picked up the trembling creature and stepped outside with a sigh.

Rachel's expression twisted when she saw the tiny snake.

"You screamed over this?" Beatrice Quincy crossed her arms, irritation sharp in her voice.

The actress looked murderous after being woken abruptly.

Rachel's lips quivered, speechless.

"Weren't you the one who bragged about catching snakes barehanded in the countryside?" Hugo Rothschild's voice was glacial.

His piercing gaze pinned Rachel in place.

Leo jutted his chin defensively. "She was ambushed!"

"Ambushed?" Hugo's laugh was icy. "This thing moves slower than a snail."

Rachel's face burned crimson. Tears welled in her eyes.

Timothy rubbed his temples. "Everyone disperse. We have filming tomorrow."

As he turned away, he couldn't suppress a weary sigh.

These siblings were becoming insufferable.
###Chapter 390

These two are absolute morons.

Their live stream viewership can't even compare to the Croix brothers' numbers.

Instead of damage control, they keep digging their own graves.

Pathetic.

They'll be completely canceled after the show.

Serves them right.

Who told them to scheme against Evelyn Laurent?

This is pure karma.

Timothy Gold is stunned.

Only one day into filming, and these contestants have already self-destructed!

Rachel and Leo Clemenson's follower count is plummeting. The entire internet is roasting them.

Timothy won't bother warning them.

They're beyond saving.

No point wasting his breath.

The drama quickly fades.

The contestants retreat to their quarters.

Some sleep like logs. Others toss and turn all night.

Beatrice Quincy belongs to the latter group.

She keeps imagining snakes slithering under her bed...

Dawn arrives before she finally dozes off.

The exhaustion leaves her looking haggard when filming resumes.

[Why does Beatrice look so tired? Bad night?]

[The Clemensons have dark circles down to their chins!]

[What happened last night?]

[Evelyn's group seems perfectly rested though.]

Viewers speculate wildly, but no one knows the truth.

Day two finds Evelyn constructing her cabin.

With all materials gathered, she works tirelessly at the campsite.

Watching her build is mesmerizing.

After laying the foundation, she weaves walls from branches and vines.

She even crafts a functional door.

Her progress is astonishingly fast.

While other teams still struggle for food, her cabin nears completion.

Ethan Sullivan and her brothers assist.

By dusk, the rustic cabin stands finished.

Crude but superior to the other teams' tents.

Timothy runs his hands through his hair in frustration.

Their pace shatters all expectations.

Their food situation is equally impressive.

All four have mastered spearfishing.

Yes, even Julian Langley finally got the hang of it after relentless practice.

Bianca Fairchild has also perfected the technique.

Their meals spark envy—fresh seafood, grilled fish, roasted rabbit.

Plus wild berries Evelyn foraged from the woods.

Tart and juicy.

Perfect palate cleansers after rich meats.

The other teams immediately copy her.

If Evelyn picked those berries, they must be safe!

Probably delicious too.
###Chapter 391

Evelyn Laurent paid no attention to the others' progress.

Even when she noticed the other three groups copying her methods—weaving grass mats, building cabins, gathering wild fruits—she merely glanced at them indifferently.

As long as they didn’t disturb her, she had no complaints.

Surprisingly, the next two days passed in unusual peace.

The other guests seemed to finally understand that survival, not competition, was the priority on this island.

Crystal Rothschild and Hugo Rothschild chose to reinforce their tent—building a cabin was too labor-intensive for just two people.

By the fourth day, all four camps had taken shape.

Evelyn’s team’s cabin remained the most impressive.

Rachel Clemenson and her brother still slept in tents. The hard bedding left Rachel sore and exhausted every morning.

Beatrice Quincy’s group had managed to build a cabin, though it stood crooked and unsteady.

Xander Quincy had woven her a comfortable grass mat, at least easing her discomfort.

Just as everyone settled into their routines, Evelyn grew restless.

She had explored nearly every corner of the island. If not for Timothy Gold stopping her, she would’ve ventured further.

Bored, she chopped down a few more trees.

This time, even Julian Langley couldn’t decipher what she was making.

She carefully stripped the bark and began carving something with her combat knife.

Julian and the others focused on gathering food.

Evelyn, however, was crafting gifts for her family.

She had decided to carve wooden figurines of them.

Though she only had a combat knife, her hands moved with astonishing precision.

The sea breeze brushed past as she worked, utterly absorbed.

Ethan Sullivan quietly gathered wild fruits, washed and sliced them, then sat beside her to feed her.

Their seamless coordination created such a warm atmosphere that Julian couldn’t help but envy them.

He tried to join, but Evelyn reminded him, "Julian, you’re blocking the light."

Grumbling, he stepped aside, shooting Ethan a resentful look.

That guy was too good at this.

Why was he always one step behind?

Julian lingered behind his sister, watching her deft fingers dance across the wood.
Twilight descended as city lights began to glow.

I stood by the floor-to-ceiling window, gazing at the glittering skyline.

My phone screen lit up suddenly. A message from Ethan Sullivan: "Meet me at our usual spot. 8 PM."

My fingers hovered over the screen before typing a single word: "Okay."

At 7:50, I pushed open the door of the secluded café.

Ethan was already seated in the corner, his slender fingers tapping rhythmically against the table.

"You're here." He looked up, his dark eyes unreadable.

I took the seat across from him. The rich aroma of coffee filled the air.

"What did you find?" I cut straight to the chase.

Ethan slid a manila envelope from his briefcase.

"Lowell Group's accounts are compromised." His voice dropped. "Someone's siphoning funds."

I flipped through the documents, my hands trembling slightly.

Each page revealed staggering sums. The endless zeros made my breath catch.

"Where is this money—" I lifted my gaze to meet his.

"Funneled into an offshore shell company." He took a sip of coffee. "Whoever's behind this is careful."

Suddenly, blinding headlights flashed through the window.

Instinctively, I turned away, shoving the files into my bag.

"Are you being followed?" Ethan's sharp eyes noticed my tension.

"Not sure." I pressed my lips together. "I've felt watched lately."

His gaze turned razor-sharp.

"Be careful around Vincent." The warning came abruptly.

My pulse jumped. "What do you mean?"

"He's been—" Ethan's words cut off as the café door burst open.

A familiar silhouette stood framed in the doorway, backlit by the streetlights.

"What a coincidence." Vincent's voice carried amused warmth. "I didn't know you two frequented this place."

My fingers tightened around my bag strap.

Ethan rose smoothly. "Mr. Lowell. Fancy seeing you here."

Vincent's gaze flickered between us. The air grew thick.

"Mind if I join you?" He pulled out the chair beside me with effortless grace.

His cologne wafted over me—spiced amber with a faint metallic tang.

"Of... course." I forced calm into my voice.

Ethan's phone vibrated sharply.

He checked the screen, his expression shifting. "Excuse me. An emergency."

Vincent smirked. "The busy life of a lawyer."

Ethan gave me a meaningful look before striding away.

Now it was just Vincent and me.

His fingers began tapping the table in the same rhythm Ethan had used earlier.

"I heard..." He leaned close, his breath warm against my ear, "you've been auditing company finances."

My blood turned to ice.

"Who told you that?" My voice came out brittle.

Vincent chuckled, his lips nearly brushing my skin.

"Nothing stays secret in this city, darling."

His hand slid to the nape of my neck. Cold as a serpent's touch.

"Especially not from you."
###Chapter 392

"My lady, I have failed you. Our outpost in the town has fallen." Yang Zuo dropped to one knee, his voice thick with suppressed fury.

The slender figure in the cave turned slowly. The violet miniskirt shimmered faintly in the dim light, revealing glimpses of pale legs. The girl's raven hair cascaded like silk, gleaming under the torchlight.

Evelyn's delicate fingers tapped lightly against the stone wall, producing crisp echoes.

"Uncle Yang, we've retreated as far as we can go." Her voice was cool, but defiance burned in her eyes.

Yang Zuo looked up at the girl's exquisite profile flickering in the firelight. The young mistress of the Sun and Moon Sect was now their last hope.

"My scouts report that the Lowell sisters and Ethan are merely passing through," Yang Zuo said grimly. "They travel without an army."

Evelyn whirled around, her skirt slicing through the air.

"Are you certain?"

"Beyond doubt." A ruthless glint flashed in Yang Zuo's eyes. "If not for Felix's interference, we would have eliminated them already."

"Felix?" Evelyn's pupils contracted. "From the Imperial City?"

Silence fell in the cave, broken only by the crackling of torches.

"My lady, retreat is no longer an option." Yang Zuo's voice turned hoarse. "We must strike first."

Evelyn walked to the cave entrance, gazing at the distant mountain ridges. The setting sun stretched her shadow long across the ground.

"How many remain with us?"

"Over ten thousand."

The girl suddenly laughed—a chilling, crystalline sound.

"You're right, Uncle Yang." When she turned, her eyes held only resolve. "If they seek our annihilation, let's see who falls first."

Yang Zuo knelt again. "I have a plan."

Evelyn arched a brow. "Speak."

"Lure them deep into Kunlun Base. Let them walk into our trap." Yang Zuo's eyes gleamed with cunning.

Evelyn ran her fingers along the coiled whip at her waist, her lips curving into a cold smile.

"Make it so." Her gentle tone sent a sudden chill through the cave. "Tonight, none of our pursuers shall leave alive."

Yang Zuo clasped his fists solemnly. "I'll arrange it at once."

Outside, dusk deepened. None could foresee the bloodbath brewing in the shadows.
###Chapter 393

Evelyn Laurent kept her head down, her fingers deftly maneuvering the carving knife.

"Of course there's one for you." Her tone was casual, as if discussing the weather.

Ethan Sullivan's lips curved slightly, his eyes shimmering with quiet delight.

He leaned back in his chair, his gaze never leaving Evelyn's hands.

At least he wouldn't have to envy Julian Langley anymore.

Bianca Fairchild inched closer, hesitating.

"You too," Evelyn said without looking up.

Bianca's eyes brightened as she immediately settled back into her seat.

The three of them watched in silence as Evelyn carved.

Wood shavings scattered as Julian's likeness gradually took shape.

"I'm going to enshrine this!" Julian cradled the finished piece like a treasure.

Evelyn shook her head. "Julian, that's unnecessary."

"But you made it with your own hands!" He stubbornly hugged the wooden figure to his chest.

Evelyn gave up arguing and picked up another block of wood.

This time, it was Ethan.

He stared intently at every movement of her hands, already deciding to save this video clip separately.

The knife glided across the wood, revealing Ethan's refined features.

Compared to the first piece, this one was noticeably more detailed.

Bianca's sculpture came next.

Then the rest of the Langley brothers.

Evelyn deliberately saved her parents' carvings for last.

She didn’t want Julian to know she’d originally planned to use Ethan’s statue as practice.

On screen, the Langley family watched, mesmerized.

The live chat exploded:

[Her technique is flawless! Every detail is perfect!]

[This reminds me of that mysterious sculptor five years ago whose works sold out instantly!]

[Could Evelyn Laurent be that legendary artist?]
###Chapter 394

The live stream comments exploded.

"Oh my god! This carving technique is divine!"

"Wait... this style looks familiar."

"Could it be NC the Legend?"

"No way. NC vanished three years ago!"

Evelyn Laurent remained absorbed in carving the wooden block, oblivious to the chatter.

Her fingers danced with practiced ease as wood shavings fluttered down.

Each stroke landed with instinctive precision.

"Done." She set down the chisel, admiring her work.

Twelve miniature statues stood in perfect formation, their clothing folds rendered in exquisite detail.

Ethan Sullivan's eyes flashed with admiration. "When did you learn this craft, Evelyn?"

Julian Langley rushed to examine the carvings. "These are uncanny!"

Evelyn massaged her sore shoulder. "Just picked it up during idle moments."

She glanced at the sky, then brightened suddenly.

"Let's chop wood for deck chairs!"

Bianca Fairchild responded instantly. "I'll help!"

Her eyes sparkled with anticipation.

These were the most carefree days she'd ever known.

No schemes from Beatrice Quincy to dodge. No icy glares from the Quincy family.

Though worried about her grandmother's safety, Bianca found unexpected solace in Evelyn's presence.

"Let's go." Evelyn grabbed an axe and headed toward the trees.

Bianca quickened her pace, making a silent vow.

She'd pay any price to save her grandmother.

Even... with her life.

Sunlight filtered through the leaves, painting dappled patterns on the ground.

Evelyn's silhouette flickered between light and shadow.

For a fleeting moment, Bianca saw her as a beacon in the darkness.
###Chapter 395

Evelyn Laurent paused briefly before nodding in agreement to Bianca Fairchild and Julian Langley's request to join her.

Having extra hands would be useful.

Besides, the sachet she wore kept snakes and insects at bay—not even mosquitoes dared approach her lately.

The four of them re-entered the dense forest.

Evelyn swung her blade with precision, felling trees one after another. This time, she deliberately chose trunks of moderate thickness for easier transport.

Back at the campsite, she requested a black marker from the production crew.

Timothy Gold silently handed her the pen, eyeing their already luxurious log cabin.

The marker had no survival value, but for them...

They might as well build a deck chair next.

Evelyn took the pen and immediately got to work.

Julian and the other two gathered around, watching in awe as her hand moved swiftly across the wood.

Their only tasks were stripping bark and cutting logs to the measurements she marked.

[What is Evelyn drawing? It looks so professional!]

[Those lines... Are those mortise and tenon joints?]

[How does she even know this?!]

The live stream exploded in popularity, viewership surpassing ten million.

The audience held their breath, wondering what surprise this prodigy would unveil next.

Wood shavings flew as the timber in Evelyn's hands gradually took shape.

"Sis, what exactly are you making?" Julian couldn't resist asking.

"A deck chair," she replied without looking up. "We can't just sit on the ground to sunbathe."

Timothy Gold and Eugene York spat out their tea simultaneously in the control room.

While other teams struggled for basic survival, these people were—building! A! Deck! Chair!

[LMAO! Others are surviving in the wild, and they're vacationing!]

[I'd love to see the other teams' reactions!]

[Evelyn is legendary! This group always breaks the mold!]

The chat erupted instantly.

Evelyn remained focused on carving the wooden slats, oblivious to becoming the internet's latest sensation.
###Chapter 396

Evelyn Laurent remained oblivious to the others' thoughts.

Her fingers traced the wood grain as she meticulously arranged lumber of various shapes.

"Measure this for me," she said without looking up at Ethan Sullivan.

Ethan immediately set down his tools and reached for the measuring tape.

Julian Langley watched in fascination. "Where did you learn these skills, little sister?"

Evelyn only smiled in response.

The sun dipped toward the horizon, casting golden light over the wooden planks covering the cabin floor.

"We can assemble it tomorrow." Evelyn stretched, her eyes alight with anticipation.

She envisioned herself reclining on the handmade deck chair, sea breeze caressing her face.

A sudden realization struck her.

Hadn't Victoria Langley gifted her an island for her birthday?

Evelyn shot to her feet, her expression shifting abruptly.

"What's wrong?" Ethan instantly noticed her change in demeanor.

"I need to see the production crew." She strode toward the exit.

Ethan fell into step beside her without hesitation. "I'm coming with you."

Julian scrambled after them. "Wait for me!"

Bianca Fairchild remained at the campsite, watching their retreating figures with thoughtful eyes.

Inside the production tent, Timothy Gold paced anxiously.

"Assistant director! Evelyn Laurent's group is approaching!" a staff member reported breathlessly.

Timothy wiped his sweaty brow. "What does she want now?"

Evelyn marched in and cut straight to the chase. "Who owns this island?"

Timothy blinked. "That's...confidential business information—"

"Do you know or not?" Evelyn's voice sharpened.

Ethan moved half a step closer, positioning himself at her side.

Timothy mopped his forehead. "We've only communicated with the owner's assistant..."

Evelyn's eyes narrowed, her pulse quickening.

Could this island truly be hers?
###Chapter 397

Julian Langley arched an eyebrow, his gaze lingering on Evelyn Laurent's face.

"Evelyn, are you asking about the owner of this island?"

Evelyn pressed her lips together and nodded.

A suspicion tugged at her mind, but she didn't dare confirm it.

Timothy Gold suddenly interjected, "Why don't you just ask Julian? He's the one who recommended this place to me."

There was no way he could've found such a perfect filming location on his own.

Julian was the mastermind behind it.

Evelyn whipped her head toward Julian.

He scratched the back of his head, looking genuinely puzzled. "Evelyn, don't you remember the island Mom gifted you?"

Timothy's eyes nearly bulged out of their sockets.

His finger trembled as he pointed at Julian.

"W-what? An island gifted to Evelyn?"

Evelyn shook her head honestly. "I don't recall."

At the time, she'd been too moved to properly examine the property documents.

Over the years, she'd received too many assets—

Luxury villas. Sports cars. Company shares.

How could she possibly remember every single one?

Julian sighed. "I thought you knew this was your island."

"Mine?"

Evelyn gasped.

Her lashes fluttered before a radiant smile bloomed across her face.

"That's perfect!"

She'd been mourning the loss of that burned-down cabin.

Now that she knew the entire island belonged to her, that shabby little hut seemed downright pathetic.

Time for renovations!

No—she'd build a seaside mansion!

Construction would start as soon as filming wrapped.

Timothy clutched his chest and staggered back two steps.

He felt like his heart was bleeding.

This revelation was too devastating!

Now he regarded Evelyn with newfound reverence.

After all...

His show's continued filming depended on the island owner's goodwill.

Ethan Sullivan stood nearby, warmth glimmering in his eyes.

He'd known the island belonged to Evelyn all along.

He'd assumed she knew too.

Who knew the scatterbrain had forgotten?

Evelyn suddenly turned toward the window, her gaze landing on the luxury yacht.

"That cruise ship—"

Ethan swiftly cut her off. "Timothy, where's that document I asked you to hold?"

Timothy hurriedly retrieved a file from the cabinet.

Ethan handed it to Evelyn without even glancing at it.

"Sign here."

Evelyn flipped open the document in confusion.

It was a yacht transfer agreement.

"Southern Cross?" she murmured, reading the name aloud.

Julian's expression darkened instantly.

That sly bastard!

He'd actually named the yacht using the second characters of both their names!

Just as Julian opened his mouth to mock him, Ethan casually slung an arm around Evelyn's shoulders.

"Do you like it?"

Evelyn bent to sign, oblivious to the tension between the two men.

The scratch of pen against paper echoed sharply in the quiet room.
###Chapter 398

Evelyn Laurent flipped through the documents in her hands, her fingertips pausing over the signature on the last page.

The name "Ethan Sullivan" was written in bold, elegant strokes, exuding an innate nobility.

She glanced up at the man beside her, the corners of her eyes lifting slightly. "You're really giving this to me?"

Ethan's lips curved into a faint smile, his gaze warm and focused. "If it makes you happy."

He would give her the world if she asked.

Evelyn abruptly closed the file and shoved it back into his hands. "I don't want it."

She hesitated before adding, "I just wanted to know where you booked this yacht."

Julian Langley, standing nearby, quietly exhaled in relief.

A flicker of surprise crossed Ethan's eyes.

Evelyn muttered under her breath, "I just don’t know what to do about seasickness..."

"You get seasick?" Ethan's expression darkened instantly.

Julian chimed in dryly, "Both of us do."

Ethan suddenly remembered Evelyn's pale face the day they arrived on the island. His chest tightened with regret. "I should have sent a helicopter for you."

Timothy Gold and Eugene York exchanged glances.

A helicopter?

Evelyn's eyes lit up. "You have a helicopter?"

Ethan chuckled, his voice low and tempting. "Not just one—I can fly it too." He leaned closer. "Want to try?"

Julian watched the scene unfold, thinking Ethan looked like a peacock flaunting its feathers.

"Absolutely!" Evelyn agreed without hesitation.

Julian rubbed his temples.

Great. His little sister was being whisked away.

Ethan made the decision on the spot. "We'll take the helicopter back after filming wraps."

The two directors huddled in the corner, clutching their modest budgets in silent despair.
###Chapter 399

Ethan Sullivan's lips curved slightly as he slid the document toward Evelyn Laurent.

"I've had this yacht prepared for you for a long time, Evelyn. It's a genuine gift."

Evelyn frowned at him.

"Why would you suddenly give me something so extravagant?"

Sunlight streamed through the porthole, illuminating the deck and making the confusion in her eyes unmistakable.

Ethan's throat moved slightly.

"Because I owe you."

All those years of letting her endure hardships, all those unnecessary agreements—they weighed heavily on his conscience.

"You don't owe me anything," Evelyn said, even more perplexed.

Julian Langley suddenly cut in.

"Oh, he definitely owes you! Just sign it, Evelyn—we're keeping this yacht!"

He shot Ethan a sharp glare as he spoke.

Evelyn shook her head.

"No, it's too much."

Her fingers absently traced the edge of the document before she realized just how little she knew about Ethan.

He remembered every detail of her preferences, yet she didn’t even know his birthday.

The realization tightened her chest.

Ethan immediately noticed the shift in her gaze, and his heart sank.

"If you won’t take it," he said, his voice lowering, "I'll donate it."

Julian nearly jumped out of his seat.

"Donate it?! Hell no—give it to me then!"

A sea breeze swept across the deck, diffusing the tension.

Evelyn watched the two men bristling at each other and found the whole scene absurdly comical.

Her gaze dropped to the gilded yacht illustration on the document, and suddenly, she remembered Ethan’s focused profile that day at the auction—when he’d won that painting for her.

"I'll take it," she said abruptly.

Both men froze.

Evelyn lifted her eyes to meet Ethan’s startled gaze and added softly,

"But on one condition."

The waves lapped against the hull, mirroring the sudden acceleration of someone’s heartbeat.
###Chapter 400

The yacht transfer procedures were incredibly tedious.

If he really wanted to donate money, why go through such a roundabout way?

A smile spread across Ethan Sullivan's eyes as he readily agreed, "If you like it, Third Brother, it's yours."

He didn't even bat an eyelid.

Julian Langley was taken aback.

Was this guy really willing to give away a multimillion-dollar yacht just to pursue Evelyn?

There had to be an ulterior motive!

Julian scoffed coldly, "If you're giving me the yacht, what will you use to impress Evelyn? Since you're so generous, Mr. Sullivan, why not throw in a couple of helicopters too?"

Helicopters weren't just something you could buy with money—they were rare luxuries.

Ethan nodded calmly. "No problem."

He smiled at Julian. "What model do you prefer, Third Brother? I'll accompany you to pick them out later."

"Deal!"

Julian blurted out before immediately pressing his lips together in frustration.

He'd agreed too quickly—it made him seem desperate.

Timothy Gold and Eugene York exchanged uneasy glances.

Could these two at least consider their feelings?

"Um..." Timothy raised a hesitant hand. "Mr. Langley, Mr. Sullivan, maybe you two should discuss this later? I'm starting to feel a little faint."

If he had to listen any longer, he might actually pass out.

Evelyn Laurent offered an apologetic smile. "Sorry for disturbing your rest."

She turned and walked out.

Now that the island ownership was confirmed, she felt much lighter.

Ethan quickly followed. "Evelyn, the yacht is yours too. And I'll add two helicopters. How does that sound?"

Evelyn stopped abruptly.

She frowned at him. "Why are you giving me such expensive gifts?"

Without waiting for his answer, she cut straight to the point. "Do you have feelings for me?"

Julian stiffened instantly.

His eyes darted between them nervously, but he chose to stay silent.

Ethan gazed deeply at Evelyn.

After a long pause, he chuckled softly. "Haven't I made it obvious enough?"

He was willing to give everything he had just to see her smile.

Evelyn pressed further. "Do you like me as I am now, or the Evelyn from back then?"

Ethan's eyes burned with intensity.

"I've figured it out."

"The one I've always loved is Evelyn Laurent."

His obsession from the past had been nothing but guilt and gratitude.

If he'd truly cared, why had he felt nothing but disgust when Sophia Lowell appeared?
###Chapter 401

The sea breeze whispered as starlight scattered across the shore.

Ethan Sullivan stood on the beach, his obsidian eyes locked onto Evelyn Laurent. His gaze held nothing but her reflection.

His heartbeat roared in his ears.

Never had he felt such nervousness. Beads of sweat formed on his palms.

Julian Langley retreated half a step, then frowned at his own hesitation. He remained silent in the shadows.

Night deepened.

The live stream had ended long ago, leaving the island in perfect stillness.

No moonlight graced the sky—only countless stars shimmering on the undulating sea.

Evelyn froze.

She never expected such a confession from Ethan.

He said the one he'd always loved was her.

From the very beginning.

Chaotic thoughts swirled through her mind.

They'd been bound by an engagement, yet resisted each other. She refused to be shackled. He waited for that little girl from his past.

Fate played its cruel joke.

That little girl turned out to be herself.

And so, the engagement dissolved.

Memories flooded her heart.

Evelyn's brow furrowed slightly as she sank into contemplation.

Ethan's heart climbed into his throat.

Had he been too impulsive?

No carefully planned setting. No romantic gestures.

Just raw honesty when she asked.

But he could no longer hide his feelings.

He loved her.

From the moment he brought her back to Oceancrest, she'd captivated him.

Her radiant defiance. Her untamed spirit.

Unlike any woman he'd ever known.

A long silence passed.

Evelyn finally lifted her gaze.

Her clear eyes met Ethan's directly.

His Adam's apple bobbed as he held his breath.

This moment felt like judgment.

"I've never known much warmth in my life."

"You were the first to protect me."

Her voice remained steady. "But Ethan, I don't understand love."

Truthfully, she didn't.

Affection itself was a luxury. Love? An entirely foreign realm.

Ethan's body stiffened.

His lips pressed into a thin line, heart aching.

Not from potential rejection.

But for all the pain she'd endured.
###Chapter 402

The ocean breeze carried a briny tang as it swept across the shore.

Evelyn Laurent clenched the hem of her coat, her fingertips trembling slightly.

"Ethan Sullivan, you do make me feel... something special." Her voice faltered, nearly drowned by the crashing waves. "But I think... we should keep things as they are."

Ethan's pupils constricted sharply.

He studied her for a long moment before forcing a bitter smile. "Understood."

An invisible fist squeezed his heart.

He took half a step back, his tone eerily calm. "I overstepped."

As he turned away, his shoulders slumped under the weight of rejection.

Moonlight stretched his solitary shadow across the sand.

Evelyn's hand hovered midair before dropping limply to her side.

A dull ache spread through her chest.

She couldn't tell if it was guilt or something else twisting inside her.

Julian Langley stood in the shadows, brows furrowed.

He'd never seen his little sister look so devastated.

Even after rejecting him, her gaze still followed Ethan's retreating figure.

Waves pounded against the jagged rocks.

Ethan sat alone at the water's edge, letting the icy surf soak through his trousers.

The night wind carried traces of Evelyn's gardenia perfume.

His fists clenched until nails bit into his palms.

He shouldn't have been impulsive.

Now even friendship was impossible.

Restless fury surged through his veins.

He sprang to his feet and strode into the deepening water.

"Ethan!"

Julian's shout shattered the night.

Evelyn burst from the cabin just as the last strands of Ethan's dark hair disappeared beneath the waves.

Her heart stopped.
###Chapter 403

The ocean erupted with a deafening blast.

Evelyn Laurent's pupils contracted violently.

Her gaze locked onto the spot where Ethan Sullivan had vanished.

Churning waves swallowed the familiar silhouette.

"Ethan!"

Her anguished scream tore through the night.

She launched herself toward the black waters like an arrow from a bow.

"Evelyn!"

Julian Langley's grasping fingers closed on empty air.

He could only watch helplessly as his sister plunged into the raging sea.

Lights blazed to life in the villa.

Timothy Gold sprinted out barefoot, not even pausing for shoes.

"Christ almighty!"

Eugene York followed close behind, his face bloodless.

Bianca Fairchild stood frozen on the shore, speechless with shock.

The seawater stabbed like ice.

Evelyn thrashed through the waves, her heart hammering against her ribs.

In the distance.

Ethan floated motionless on the dark surface.

Moonlight traced the pallor of his profile.

Evelyn's fingertips trembled.

She swam desperately toward him.

Water sprayed as she seized his arm.

"Hold on!"

She broke the surface with him, her voice cracking.

Ethan's eyes flew open.

When their gazes met.

He saw her red-rimmed eyes.

"You—"

Before he could finish, Evelyn was already dragging him toward shore.

"Medic! Call an ambulance!"

Chaos erupted on the beach.

Understanding dawned on Ethan.

He gripped her wrist.

"I wasn't—"

"Shut up!" Evelyn snapped. "Save your strength!"

Wet strands clung to her face, droplets clinging to her lashes.

Ethan suddenly smiled.

Through the roar of waves.

He heard his own thunderous heartbeat.
###Chapter 404

Timothy Gold paced nervously along the shoreline, beads of sweat glistening on his forehead.

Evelyn Laurent's figure dragging Ethan Sullivan toward the shore stood out starkly under the moonlight.

In the distance, hurried footsteps approached as the hastily awakened medical team sprinted toward them with first aid kits.

The sea shimmered with silver ripples.

Ethan hesitated for only a second.

"Evelyn."

His voice was soft.

She froze mid-motion and turned to look at him.

Under the moonlight, his eyes were crystal clear.

Her arms stiffened in the water.

Ethan sighed. "I won a swimming championship at six. I can hold my breath for five minutes."

"I just needed some quiet time in the water."

His words were quiet but deliberate.

He could have pretended to faint.

But he couldn't bear to.

Couldn't bear to see her panic.

And he refused to lie to her.

Such a clumsy act wouldn't hold up under scrutiny.

Evelyn's fingers trembled slightly.

A sudden realization hit her—

She had been a fool.

Her grip on Ethan loosened abruptly.

She had used every ounce of strength to drag him ashore.

The weight in her chest finally lifted.

For a moment, she thought she'd lost him forever.

Ethan watched her flustered expression, warmth flickering in his eyes. "You were worried about me?"

Though phrased as a question, it carried certainty.

Evelyn turned her face away. "I didn't want you dying here and ruining the mood."

Her voice wavered.

Ethan chuckled lowly. "I don't plan on dying."

His tone was serious.

After surviving a childhood of schemes to reach where he was today—

More importantly—

He hadn't won her over yet.

The tips of Evelyn's ears flushed pink. "Oh."

The sea breeze brushed past, but her heartbeat refused to steady.

Ethan gently took her hand. "The water's cold. Let's go back."

"Mm."

After swimming just two meters, Evelyn suddenly paled.

A sharp pain shot through her right leg, and she sank beneath the waves.

Ethan reacted instantly, pulling her back up.

Onshore, frantic footsteps echoed as a lifebuoy was thrown into the sea.

He held her shivering body tightly.

Instinctively, she wrapped her arms around his neck.

The crew hauled them both onto the sand.

Julian Langley rushed over, his voice shaking. "What happened?"

The night wind cut like ice.

Timothy swiftly wrapped them both in blankets.

Ethan ignored the question, his hands massaging Evelyn's cramped calf. "Does it still hurt?"
###Chapter 405

Evelyn Laurent had always been in excellent physical condition.

But that burst of energy was astonishing. She sprinted toward the shore at an incredible speed and plunged into the icy seawater without hesitation. The intense mental strain finally took its toll on her calf muscles.

Only when she confirmed Ethan Sullivan was safe did her nerves relax slightly. The moment she let her guard down, the pain of cramping seized her.

Fortunately, Ethan reacted swiftly.

His large, well-defined hands pressed firmly against her cramped calf, applying just the right amount of pressure.

The pain soon subsided.

After a brief hesitation, she offered him half of her blanket. "Don’t catch a cold either."

A flicker of warmth passed through Ethan's eyes.

Julian Langley finally snapped out of his daze and threw a spare blanket at Ethan. He rushed to his sister’s side and wrapped her tightly. "Evelyn, how could you be so reckless?"

He hadn’t even had time to stop her.

It had started with a worried shout for Ethan.

But Evelyn’s reaction was alarmingly intense.

Worse, she had seen the exact moment Ethan submerged beneath the waves.

Julian’s heart ached for her.

Evelyn pressed her lips together, silent.

Ethan continued massaging her calf, casually draping the blanket over himself, his gaze never leaving her.

"Get on the boat and rest. Don’t risk getting sick," urged Timothy Gold, still shaken by the incident.

The commotion had drawn everyone’s attention.

Beatrice Quincy and the others hurried over, only to learn it was a false alarm. Rachel Clemenson couldn’t resist sneering, "Such an overreaction."

Leo Clemenson quickly silenced her.

Rachel scoffed and stormed off.

Resentment radiated from her, especially toward Evelyn.

Why did Evelyn get to enjoy a luxurious island getaway while they struggled to survive?

All because of her family’s wealth.

No one paid Rachel’s bitterness any mind.

Hugo Rothschild stood at a distance, his dark eyes fixed on Evelyn as she was helped onto the boat. He shot Ethan a cold glare before turning away.

Hot water washed away the seawater clinging to her skin.

Only then did Evelyn fully realize what she had done.

She had jumped into the ocean without hesitation—to save Ethan.

Turns out, he was just practicing breath-holding exercises.

To make things worse, she had been cradled in his arms in front of everyone.

The image of them sharing a blanket refused to leave her mind.

Her cheeks suddenly burned.

Her heartbeat raced uncontrollably.

She pressed a hand to her chest. "Am I running a fever?"

The water had been freezing.

She quickly dried her hair and slipped under the covers.

Maybe sleep would fix it.
###Chapter 406

Ethan Sullivan stood under the shower, letting the warm water cascade over his body.

The image of Evelyn Laurent clinging to him replayed in his mind.

Her slender arms had encircled his waist, the faint fragrance of her hair lingering in the air.

He abruptly turned off the faucet. Water droplets slid from his damp hair.

Taking a deep breath, he grabbed a towel and roughly dried his hair.

The mirror reflected his slightly flushed earlobes.

This unexpected encounter confirmed one thing—Evelyn was different to him.

Ethan lay on the bed, facing the wall.

His fingertips lightly traced the rough wooden surface.

Just beyond this partition was Evelyn's bed.

The realization made his pulse quicken.

One day, this barrier would be broken.

Morning sunlight filtered through the curtains.

Evelyn rubbed her eyes and stretched, refreshed.

Oblivious to last night's incident, she yawned as usual.

When she opened her door, Ethan emerged from the adjacent room at the same moment.

"Morning," Ethan greeted with his usual composure.

"Morning," Evelyn smiled back.

Both silently agreed not to mention what had happened.

The scent of cooking drifted from the beach camp.

Julian Langley waved a ladle. "Evelyn! The fish stew is ready!"

She hurried over and accepted the steaming bowl.

The savory aroma dispelled the morning chill.

Her eyes crinkled with satisfaction as she glanced at the materials piled nearby.

"Let's finish the deck chairs today."

The live stream began on schedule, viewers flooding in instantly.

[Finally!]

[What's today's project? So excited!]

Evelyn efficiently sorted the lumber.

Julian blinked in confusion. "Is there a difference between these planks?"

She answered with an enigmatic smile, deftly selecting suitable pieces.

The rasp of sawing soon echoed across the shore.
###Chapter 407

Sunlight filtered through palm fronds, casting dappled shadows on the sand.

Evelyn Laurent's slender fingers moved deftly over wooden blocks, each mortise and tenon joint fitting seamlessly.

A soft click sounded.

The final piece slid perfectly into place.

A rustic deck chair took shape before their eyes.

[Damn! That craftsmanship is insane!]

[My grandpa was a carpenter—this level of skill takes at least twenty years to master.]

[What kind of goddess is Evelyn?]

The live stream exploded with comments.

Julian Langley's jaw nearly hit the ground.

"Evelyn, don't tell me you can build houses too?"

She brushed wood dust from her hands, lips quirking.

"A little."

Ethan Sullivan handed her a coconut, admiration gleaming in his eyes.

"A little? That was master-level work."

Bianca Fairchild leaned in for a closer look—

When frantic footsteps suddenly pounded toward them.

"Help!"

Beatrice Quincy stumbled into camp, disheveled.

Her dress was torn by thorns, face pale with terror.

"Bianca! Save Xander!"

Bianca shot to her feet.

"What happened?"

Beatrice gripped her sister's arm, nails digging in.

"We—we were at the north slope—"

A violent cough wracked her body.

Evelyn was at her side in an instant, steadying her trembling shoulders.

"Breathe. Get to the point."

The icy command made Beatrice flinch.

"Liam fell off the cliff. Xander and the others went after him, but—"

Her eyes rolled back as she collapsed.

Silence swallowed the beach.

Ethan checked her pulse.

"Shock-induced fainting. She'll be out for a while."

Julian grabbed his pack, ready to bolt.

"I'm going after them."

"Stop."

Evelyn's voice cut like steel.

Her gaze narrowed toward the shadowed northern woods.

"Something's wrong."

Bianca stamped her foot.

"But Xander—"

Evelyn was already tying up her hair, machete in hand.

"Ethan, stay with her."

She turned to Julian.

"Let's move."

They vanished into the tree line.

The live chat held its breath.

[This is bad.]

[Isn't the north slope off-limits?]

[Where's the production crew?]

Deep in the jungle, Evelyn halted.

"Wait."

She crouched, fingertips grazing a leaf.

Dull red stains glared against the sunlight.

Julian inhaled sharply.

"That's not—"

Evelyn's eyes turned glacial.

"Not from an accidental injury."

She stood slowly, grip tightening on the machete.

"Someone smeared this here on purpose."
###Chapter 408

The rain poured down in torrents, each drop stinging like pebbles against the skin.

Evelyn Laurent yanked the raincoat over her shoulders with practiced efficiency.

"Move!"

Her voice was ice, her gaze unflinching.

Beatrice Quincy's eyes were red-rimmed with panic. "It's that mountain ahead!" she cried, voice cracking.

Chaos engulfed the production crew. Drones retreated as live feeds blinked out one by one.

"Safety first, everyone!"

Timothy Gold's shout dissolved into thunder.

The mountain path had become a mudslide.

Beatrice slipped, knees slamming against jagged rock. She gritted her teeth and kept leading.

"Here!"

Her trembling finger pointed toward the cliff's edge.

Shattered vines littered the ground. Fresh scrape marks scarred the rock face.

"Xander Quincy! Liam Croix!"

Ethan Sullivan's call vanished into the howling wind.

The rescue team secured ropes with military precision.

Evelyn inspected her gear, eyes sharp as honed steel.

"I'm going with you."

Bianca Fairchild gripped her arm, rainwater dripping from his jawline.

Evelyn shook her head. "We'll cover more ground separately."

She clipped the carabiner and stepped into the void without hesitation.

Rain blurred her vision.

One hand gripping the cliffside, she searched through the deluge.

"Watch your footing!"

Ethan's warning crackled through the radio.

Her boot slipped.

Fingers locked onto an outcrop at the last second.

Blood mixed with rainwater from her torn palm.

"Fine."

The single word transmitted before she descended further.

Dense foliage swallowed the cliff base. Visibility dropped to zero.

Evelyn squinted. A flash of orange pierced the gloom.

"Found them!"

Her voice cut through the storm.
###Chapter 409

The rain poured in torrents as violent winds howled.

Timothy Gold paced frantically along the cliff's edge, veins bulging on his forehead. His fists clenched so tightly his nails dug deep into his palms.

Beatrice Quincy collapsed in the muddy ground, tears mingling with the rain as they streamed down her face. Her gaze remained fixed on the abyss below, lips trembling wordlessly.

On the deck of the Southern Cross, Julian Langley slammed his fist against the railing. He tried multiple times to rush to the rescue, only to be restrained by the crew.

"Let me go! That's my sister!" His furious roar was swallowed by the storm.

The live stream's danmu exploded with messages:

[This weather is terrifying! Please stay safe!]

[I cried when Evelyn Laurent rushed out—Ethan Sullivan chasing after her was so heroic!]

[Bianca Fairchild ran so fast she lost her shoes—now that's true sibling devotion!]

Victoria Langley stood by the window, hands balled into fists. Rain lashed against the glass like the frantic pounding of her heart.

"God, please..." she whispered, eyes locked on the distant cliffs.

Below the precipice, Evelyn Laurent's raincoat tore against jagged branches. Wiping rainwater from her face, she pressed forward in her search.

"Split up!" Ethan Sullivan called to her. "Stay alert!"

Evelyn nodded before disappearing into another thicket. Her flashlight beam flickered weakly through the downpour.

Bianca Fairchild was the first to reach the ravine's base. Muddy water already swallowed her ankles, each step a struggle.

"Xander Quincy!" Her shout was drowned by thunder.

Then—she spotted claw marks on the rockface. Following the trail, her eyes landed on the faint outline of a pitch-black cave.

Her pulse spiked. Stumbling forward, she ran toward the cavern, rain dripping from her hair.

Was someone inside?

Hands shaking, she raised her flashlight. The beam pierced the darkness...
###Chapter 410

The beam of a tactical flashlight sliced through the darkness as Bianca Fairchild burst into the cave.

Two familiar voices rang out in the gloom.

"Someone's here!"

"I knew the production crew wouldn't abandon us!"

The voices of Liam and Lucas Croix instantly eased her strained nerves.

Rounding the corner, she found the mud-caked brothers struggling to their feet.

A motionless figure lay at the cave's center.

Bianca's blood turned to ice when she recognized the deathly pale face.

"Xander!"

She stumbled forward.

Xander Quincy's eyes remained closed, his right leg caked with blood. Worse still, a broken tree branch protruded from his side.

Liam's voice shook. "He saved us..."

Her fingers trembled as she fired the emergency flare.

The crimson streak pierced the curtain of rain.

She stared at the embedded branch, not daring to touch it. Blood still seeped out, staining the muddy ground.

The rescue team arrived with impressive speed.

Ethan Sullivan and Evelyn Laurent rushed into the cave, both freezing at the horrific scene.

A stretcher descended slowly from the cliff above.

Medics secured Xander with practiced gentleness, every movement measured and careful.

As the stretcher began ascending, Bianca grabbed the rope. "I'm going up with him!"

"Negative!" The team leader barked. "You'll endanger the patient!"

Helpless, she watched her brother rise toward the precipice.

Through the downpour, Bianca staggered down the mountain. Branches tore through her raincoat, leaving bloody scratches she barely noticed.

Evelyn frowned at the distraught figure disappearing into the storm.

When the surgical lights flickered on aboard the Southern Cross, Bianca finally collapsed onto the deck.

She stared at her mud-and-blood-streaked hands before burying her face in them.

Ethan stood silent at the corridor's end.

The operating room doors burst open. A nurse rushed out. "We need more plasma!"

Bianca's head snapped up, her face paler than the patient's.
###Chapter 411 

Evelyn Laurent crouched down, her fingertips brushing against Bianca Fairchild's icy wrist.

"Don't be afraid."

Her voice was soft yet carried undeniable strength.

Bianca's unfocused gaze gradually sharpened, her lips curving into a strained smile.

"Mmm..."

She looked down at her tightly clasped hands, her knuckles turning white.

The infirmary reeked of antiseptic.

Liam and Lucas Croix sat in the corner as medical staff bandaged their wounds. Through the layers of gauze, their eyes kept darting toward the closed operating room door.

The production crew had issued an emergency broadcast suspension.

The hurricane had devastated nearly every structure on the island. Beatrice Quincy's wooden cabin had collapsed, while Rachel Clemenson and Crystal Rothschild's tent had vanished without a trace.

Only Evelyn's group's small cabin remained standing amidst the storm.

Online discussions had exploded into chaos.

At the Quincy mansion, Mr. and Mrs. Quincy's faces paled when they received the news.

"Is Beatrice alright?"

That was their first question.

Only after confirming their daughter's safety did they remember to ask about their son's condition.

Beatrice paced outside the operating room.

"Timothy Gold!" Her voice suddenly rose. "My brother is critically injured, and you're just letting him die here?"

Timothy shot her a cold glance.

"The medical facilities on the yacht are more advanced than the mainland hospitals." His tone simmered with suppressed anger. "Do you want everyone to die by setting sail now?"

Beatrice was left speechless.

She glared at Timothy's retreating back, her nails digging deep into her palms.

When her gaze shifted to Bianca in the corner, a flash of venom crossed her eyes.

This jinx!

The operating room doors suddenly swung open.

Bianca sprang to her feet, her soaked hem dragging a wet trail across the floor.

"Doctor!"

Her voice trembled as if grasping at her last lifeline.

Beatrice also hurried forward, water droplets from her hair splattering onto the sterile floor.

Both women remained in their post-drowning disarray, neither having changed out of their wet clothes.
###Chapter 412

Bianca Fairchild stood drenched at the infirmary doorway, her hair dripping. Her face was paler than Xander Quincy's on the hospital bed.

"The branch penetrated about three centimeters. Fractured left tibia. Cracked third and fourth ribs on the right side." The doctor removed his mask. "Multiple soft tissue contusions. Immediate evacuation is recommended."

At the words "no life-threatening injuries," Bianca's legs buckled. She nearly collapsed.

Liam and Lucas Croix stood in the corner. Though only lightly injured, they hung their heads like guilty children. Xander had shielded them with his body during the tumble down the slope.

Timothy Gold and Eugene York crouched at the end of the hallway. The two grown men clutched their hair like drowned rats. The yacht rocked with the waves as rain lashed against the windows.

"Did you release the statement?" Timothy's voice was hoarse.

Eugene stared at his phone screen. "Sent. Said we'll evacuate once the weather clears." He locked the screen abruptly. "The internet must be exploding right now."

Inside the infirmary, the monitor beeped steadily. Evelyn Laurent stood by the bed, gazing at Xander's bandaged body.

"Evie!" Julian Langley burst in and grabbed her wrist. "Are you okay?"

Evelyn shook her head, her eyes fixed on Bianca. The usually poised woman now gripped the bed rail with white-knuckled intensity.

Ethan Sullivan appeared at the doorway, idly shuffling a deck of cards. "Anyone up for poker?"

"Poker?" Evelyn blinked in confusion.

Julian perked up immediately. "It's a three-player card game!" He leaned closer to Evelyn's ear. "We'll make Ethan lose his shirt."

A flash of lightning illuminated Ethan's smirk. "Ten grand a hand. You in?"

The yacht lurched violently with another wave, scattering the cards across the floor. The survival challenge on this storm-wracked island had proven far deadlier than any of them imagined.
###Chapter 413

Ethan Sullivan's lips curved with an elusive smile as his gaze lingered on Julian Langley's face. "Third brother, made up your mind?"

His light tone sent a chill down Julian's spine.

Memories of their past poker games flashed through his mind—how he'd always lost spectacularly.

"Of course!" Julian lifted his chin with confidence.

This was Evelyn's first time playing. His odds were excellent.

Besides, would Ethan dare keep winning against him? If so, Julian would make sure Evelyn saw right through him.

Before dealing, Julian shot Ethan a warning glare.

Ethan was far too sharp.

Having known the Langley brothers for years, he recognized that threatening look instantly.

He sighed inwardly.

Third brother...

This time, I really can't save your wallet.

But losing to Evelyn? You won't mind, will you?

Lowering his lashes to hide his amusement, Ethan began dealing the cards.

Though Evelyn Laurent had never played poker before, her expression shifted the moment she picked up her hand.

Her focus locked onto the cards.

The first round was just a warm-up.

As expected, Evelyn lost.

Julian grinned triumphantly.

If even he could win, his luck must be phenomenal today. Clearly, Evelyn was a novice, and Ethan was going easy on her.

But by the end of the second round, his smile froze.

Then the third... the fourth...

Julian grew quieter with each game.

Evelyn had only needed one round to grasp the rules.

From the second game onward, she dominated effortlessly.

Her brilliance was undeniable—photographic memory, flawless calculations.

She anticipated every move with uncanny precision.

After over a dozen consecutive losses, Julian was on the verge of collapse.

It made no sense.

How could Evelyn be this good?

Just like when their sixth brother had introduced them to gaming—she'd mastered the controls in one round before annihilating them all.

Now history repeated itself.

Evelyn was unstoppable.

Finally, Julian understood Ethan's earlier remark.

It had been a warning that he'd inevitably lose to Evelyn.

But losing to his little sister?

He didn't mind at all.

With that realization, Julian's laughter returned, bright and carefree.

Though truthfully, Ethan suffered the heaviest losses.

Time flew by in their joyous match.

When the game concluded, Evelyn stretched lazily, reluctant for it to end.

Her winnings totaled three million.

Ethan had lost two million.

Julian trailed behind with one million in losses.
###Chapter 414

"Evelyn, you're amazing!" Julian Langley's eyes sparkled. "Winning so many rounds on your first try!"

He couldn't be prouder of his little sister.

The more brilliant she was, the less likely she'd be interested in that Ethan Sullivan.

Evelyn Laurent shook her head slightly, her gaze lingering meaningfully on Ethan. "Third Brother, Ethan was going easy on us."

She'd seen through his strategy.

Several times, he could've won but deliberately held back.

Since he seemed to be enjoying himself, she hadn't called him out—until now.

Julian's face fell instantly.

"You two..." He sighed dramatically. "You're not even human!"

Outsmarted at every turn.

Evelyn laughed softly. "Don't be upset, Third Brother. I'll have Ethan transfer all the winnings to you."

"No!" Julian waved his hands frantically. "You earned that fair and square."

Ethan watched Evelyn with tender warmth.

Every moment with her felt like a dream.

As dusk settled, the storm finally ceased.

The post-rain air was crisp and refreshing.

Evelyn hopped off the yacht eagerly.

"Solid ground feels so much better," she breathed deeply.

The constant swaying had been unsettling.

Ethan followed close behind, chuckling. "Agreed."

Suddenly, Evelyn frowned, her sharp eyes darting toward the far side of the island.

"Do you hear that?" she whispered.

Ethan tensed. "Engine sounds."

Their eyes met in silent understanding.

Ethan spun toward the yacht.

Evelyn vanished into the dense foliage like a shadow.

"Code red!" Ethan pounded on Timothy Gold's door. "Initiate evacuation. Launch the drone feed!"

Without waiting for a response, he sprinted after Evelyn.

Timothy complied immediately, though confused.

When the drone footage appeared, he gasped.

On the opposite shore, a fishing boat had docked.

A dozen foreigners scouted the area.

One suddenly raised his weapon.

BANG!

The gunshot shattered the night.
###Chapter 415

Bang—

A muffled sound pierced the night.

The surveillance screen in front of Timothy Gold went black. The drone's signal vanished completely.

The live stream cut off abruptly.

The sudden late-night broadcast of Siblings had already caught viewers off guard.

Yet, a flood of loyal fans had still rushed into the stream.

They witnessed armed personnel boarding the island and the chilling moment the drone was shot down.

[Oh my god! What's happening?]
[These aren't our military!]
[They're armed! Advancing toward the island's center!]
[Wait—is that Evelyn Laurent and Ethan Sullivan? Where are they going?]

The internet erupted instantly.

Timothy's fingers flew across the keyboard.

He immediately dialed the coast guard, reporting the exact coordinates and requesting emergency backup.

The last thing the surveillance feed captured was Evelyn and Ethan disappearing swiftly into the darkness.

"Damn it!"

Timothy slammed his fist on the desk.

Neither of them had taken their earpieces or GPS bracelets when they left the ship.

Now there was no way to contact them.

These were two high-profile guests with special statuses—how could they act recklessly in a crisis?

A cold sweat broke out on Timothy's forehead.

All he could do was pray they returned safely.

Then—

On the surveillance feed, Evelyn suddenly looked up.

Her icy gaze pierced through the lens. "Fall back. Don't get in the way."

Timothy froze.

In the way?

She was telling the entire production crew to evacuate?

But with the situation escalating, he didn't have time to overthink it.

An unnatural sound came from the shoreline.

He whipped around.

Two rubber boats had landed silently.

Four armed figures stepped onto the island, their gun barrels glinting coldly under the moonlight.

"Everyone, assemble now! Armed intruders on the island!"

Timothy's voice trembled over the broadcast.

Rachel Clemenson scoffed. "What script is this now?"

Leo Clemenson lounged on the couch. "Just special effects. I'm not falling for it."

The other guests gathered one by one.

Only Bianca Fairchild remained by Xander Quincy's side as he lay unconscious.

Through the window, she spotted shadowy figures approaching and tightened her grip on the medical scissors.

Julian Langley burst into the room first.

"Where's Evelyn?"

His gaze swept over the crowd—then his face drained of color.
###Chapter 416

Timothy Gold stared at the drone footage, his fingers trembling slightly.

"She told us to retreat, but now it's too late."

Julian Langley leaned closer to the screen, his pupils constricting sharply.

Evelyn Laurent's figure appeared unmistakably on the isolated island!

Even more alarming were the armed shadows scattered through the dense forest—far more than anticipated.

Ethan Sullivan and Evelyn moved swiftly under the cover of darkness, weaving through thick vegetation. Their agile movements made it clear they were tracking these intruders.

"They're investigating who these people are," Timothy murmured.

Before he could finish, rough shouts erupted from the deck.

"Everyone on board, come out now!"

The heavily accented command was followed by four dark figures boarding the yacht, kicking open cabin doors one by one.

With a loud crash, Rachel Clemenson's door was violently forced open.

"What the hell is going on? Has the production crew lost their minds?" Rachel rubbed her eyes, cursing loudly.

Her voice cut off abruptly.

Four gleaming weapons were pointed directly at her chest.

The lead brute licked his lips. "Tender meat. Delicious."

Rachel's legs gave out, and she collapsed to the floor.

The scene spread across the live stream, sending the chat into chaos.

[Oh God! Pirates!]

[Call the police! Send coordinates!]

[They have guns! Someone help them!]

Rachel trembled violently, forcing a smile more pitiful than a sob. "I—I don't taste good..."

Timothy slammed his fist onto the console. "Those idiots!"

He watched helplessly as Rachel and her brother were roughly bound and dragged out like cargo.

"Don't kill me! I have money! Lots of it!" Rachel shrieked hysterically.

A sharp slap silenced her instantly.

Three pirates stayed behind to guard the hostages while the others began systematically searching the yacht.

"Come out on your own," a hoarse threat echoed through the hallway. "Hand over your valuables, and we'll spare your lives."

Cold metal glinted ominously under the moonlight.
###Chapter 417

"What? They want us to pay?" Julian Langley slammed the table, his eyes flashing with fury.

He tore open his collar, revealing well-defined arm muscles.

"Who the hell do they think they are?"

Timothy Gold quickly grabbed his shoulder. "Julian, calm down!"

Julian scoffed and shook him off. "Sixty people scared of three lowlifes? They wouldn’t dare shoot."

Hugo Rothschild adjusted his cuffs with deliberate calm. "Julian’s right."

His sharp gaze lifted. "We’re not lambs for slaughter."

The cruise corridor echoed with the pirates' taunts.

Julian cracked his knuckles.

"Damn it!"

He flung open the cabin door and lunged at the armed pirate like a panther.

Hugo followed with a swift side kick to the gut.

"Ah—!"

The pirate collapsed, his gun skidding across the floor.

Julian snatched it up—then froze.

"It’s real!"

Before the other two pirates could react, the crew swarmed and pinned them down.

On deck, the remaining pirate paled.

He yanked Rachel Clemenson against him, pressing a knife to her throat.

"Don’t move!" he snarled. "One step closer, and I slit her neck!"

Rachel trembled, tears streaming.

"P-please... help..."

Regret twisted her insides.

Why had she opened that door?

Why had she doubted the crew’s warnings?

Now she’d dragged herself and her brother into the lion’s den.

The pirate’s blade glinted coldly.

"Back off!" he barked. "Or she dies now!"

Julian’s fists clenched white.

Hugo’s eyes narrowed to slits.

Everyone stood paralyzed.

The salty wind carried Rachel’s desperate sobs into the void.
###Chapter 418

The flare split the night sky. Evelyn Laurent's pupils contracted sharply.

"They have reinforcements."

Her fingers whitened around the dagger's hilt.

Ethan Sullivan lay motionless in the bushes beside her, his breathing barely audible. "At least three squads incoming."

The sea breeze carried salt and decay through the palm fronds.

Evelyn squinted. Shadows darted behind distant boulders—too fluid, too practiced. These weren't amateurs.

"Not regular pirates," she whispered. "Their formations are military-grade."

Moonlight carved Ethan's profile into something glacial.

"Black Sharks." The name dropped like shrapnel. "Southeast Asia's most vicious syndicate. Hijacked a merchant vessel last year."

Evelyn's nails bit into her palms. She remembered last month's news—a vanished cargo ship, thirty crewmen still missing.

"So they're after—"

"This island's strategic position." Ethan cut her off. "It commands the shipping lane."

Crunching shells.

Both froze.

A scar-faced mercenary passed five meters away, assault rifle sweeping. The infrared dot danced across tree trunks like a malevolent firefly.

Evelyn's muscles coiled.

"Hold." Ethan's breath grazed her ear. "He's probing."

As predicted, the mercenary spun and fired three rounds into the shrubs. Bullets grazed Evelyn's hair, scorching the air.

"Two hundred meters southeast—sniper." Ethan's voice was Arctic calm. "On three, roll to nine o'clock."

Copper flooded Evelyn's mouth. She'd bitten through her lip.

"One."

Boots advanced.

"Two."

A scope glinted in the palms.

"Three!"

Evelyn exploded forward as a suppressed shot spat past. Her former cover sprouted a smoking hole.

Ethan vanished.

The mercenary gurgled—a crimson line opened across his throat. As he collapsed, Evelyn glimpsed Ethan's silhouette slicing through moonlight like a specter.

The boardroom strategist moved with Special Forces lethality.

Shrill whistles pierced the night. More footfalls converged.

Evelyn pressed against boulders, her palms slick. This wasn't chance—it was a coordinated assault.

Her satellite phone glowed: NO SIGNAL.

"Jammed." Ethan reappeared, his tactical gear dark with blood. "They brought disruptors."

Evelyn seized his wrist.

"Who are you really?"

Moonlight caught his smile—gentle as a knife's edge. He pressed something cold into her hand.

A dragon insignia.

Her breath stalled.

She knew this emblem. The Navy's most elite unit: Leviathan.

"That shipwreck three years ago." Ethan's whisper carried the weight of torpedoes. "Was no accident."

Explosions rocked the island's far side. In the firestorm's glow, Evelyn saw the predator in Ethan's eyes.

"Now," he racked the rifle's slide, "let's educate these vermin on territorial sovereignty."
###Chapter 419

The flare tore through the night sky.

A dozen shadowy figures darted toward the crimson glow like phantoms.

Ethan Sullivan and Evelyn Laurent exchanged a glance.

They sprinted in unison toward the same direction.

On the deck of the Southern Cross, Julian Langley had three pirates bound tightly.

Inside the cabin, the last remaining assailant pressed a knife against Rachel and Leo Clemenson's throats.

The two sides faced off across the staircase.

The pirate snarled, flecks of spit flying from his mouth.

Julian rolled up his sleeves, shedding his Oscar-winning actor persona.

He unleashed a stream of expletives with perfect enunciation.

Beatrice Quincy's eyes widened.

She never imagined the refined Julian could swear with such vigor.

Timothy Gold stomped his foot in frustration. "Mind the live stream! Have some decorum!"

The crew brandished baseball bats and metal pipes, shoving the three captives forward as human shields.

Suddenly, the pirates dragged the Clemenson siblings to the bow.

The cold barrel of a gun pressed against their temples.

"Release them!" The lead pirate barked in broken English. "Or there will be blood!"

Julian sneered. "You dare cause trouble in these waters? Who gave you the audacity?"

Hugo Rothschild stepped forward, speaking fluent Filipino.

Julian turned to him, bewildered. "What did he say?"

"Tell them we're live." Hugo narrowed his eyes. "The entire nation is watching."

The pirate leader's face paled. His gun trembled slightly.

The whirring of drones pierced through the ocean breeze.

The red dots of camera lenses flickered in the darkness.
###Chapter 420

The salty sea wind whipped across the deck, thickening the air with tension.

Hugo Rothschild's words hung unfinished as the pirates' faces darkened.

Grimacing expressions twisted their sun-baked features, flashing jagged teeth as they whispered among themselves.

Julian Langley's knuckles whitened around his weapon.

Every passenger aboard the luxury yacht stood frozen.

The pirates erupted in shrill laughter.

Their scar-faced leader barked in broken English: "Hand her over or we sink this ship!"

Rachel Clemenson was dragged roughly to the railing, moonlight glinting off the blade at her throat.

Crimson beads welled against her pale neck.

Hugo shoved his captive forward, pressing his combat knife against the man's windpipe.

"Try me." His voice cut colder than the ocean breeze. "Let's see who bleeds first."

The pirate captain's eyes gleamed with malice.

Suddenly, searchlights pierced the distant waves.

"Our reinforcements!" The pirates cheered, waving their weapons.

Timothy Gold snapped orders: "Full speed ahead!"

Engines roared through the night.

Panic seized the pirates. "They're actually running!"

"I thought these people valued loyalty above all!"

Leo Clemenson collapsed to his knees, despair etching his face.

The Southern Cross loomed against the moon like a sleek leviathan.

The pirates' greedy eyes clung to the yacht's polished hull.

"Don't let them escape!" The scarred leader fired a flare gun.

A red streak split the sky.

Distant lights accelerated toward them.

Hugo narrowed his eyes. "Battle stations."

Hearts pounded in unison.

Tonight would drown in blood.
###Chapter 421

The Southern Cross's engines rumbled low and deep.

The luxury liner slowly pulled away from the dock.

The pirates ignored this, continuing their frenzied climb onto the ship.

Silent signals passed through the air.

Shadows lurking in the darkness slipped into the water, swimming toward the vessel like predatory fish.

"Stop that ship!"

Someone hissed the command.

The massive Southern Cross began turning in the water.

Even at full throttle, the colossal ship needed time to accelerate.

Timothy Gold gripped the railing.

He regretted not abandoning the Clemenson siblings sooner.

But it was too late for regrets now.

The sound of chaotic footsteps echoed across the deck.

The pirates had boarded.

Evelyn Laurent narrowed her eyes.

She and Ethan Sullivan hid in the shadows, observing the unfolding chaos.

"Something's wrong," Ethan murmured. "They're too organized."

The pirates moved with trained precision, fanning out strategically.

Some seized the bridge while others secured the deck.

The production crew retreated under the onslaught.

Blood began spreading across the wooden planks.

Evelyn dug her nails into her palms.

This was her ship.

Her island.

Now overrun by these lawless invaders.

"Don't act rashly." Ethan pressed a firm hand on her shoulder. "We'll split up."

He pointed toward the distance. "I'll draw them away."

"You take the boat."

Evelyn nodded.

Ethan suddenly burst from cover.

He shouted in Filipino dialect: "Someone escaped into the jungle!"

His voice carried sharply on the sea wind.

A dozen pirates immediately changed course.

The battle aboard the ship was nearing its end.

The production team had been forced into a corner.

The pirate leader waved a gun, counting captives.

Evelyn slipped silently into the water.

Icy ocean enveloped her.

The Southern Cross's shadow loomed overhead.

Like a shark, she glided toward her prey.
###Chapter 422

The pirates grinned maliciously as they knocked the production crew to the ground. Only Julian Langley and Hugo Rothschild remained standing back-to-back, barely holding their ground.

Blood splattered across the cruise ship's cockpit windows.

The pirate leader puffed on a cigar, smugly dispatching half his men to chase Ethan Sullivan.

Only five guards remained on deck.

Hidden in the shadows, Evelyn Laurent narrowed her eyes.

She moved like a panther poised to strike, silent and lethal in the darkness.

The baseball bat sliced through the air.

The first pirate crumpled with a grunt.

The second barely turned before a kick shattered his kneecap.

The third didn't even reach for his gun.

In under three minutes, the deck fell silent again.

Evelyn shook out her tingling wrist and vaulted over the railing.

She hauled Rachel and Leo Clemenson onto the deck like stray kittens.

"Set sail!"

Without looking back, she sprinted toward the jungle.

Julian lunged for the railing, eyes wild, but Timothy Gold gripped his shoulder like a vise.

"You'll get her killed!"

The cruise ship's engines roared to life.

The trussed-up pirates stared in horror.

Crystal Rothschild suddenly screamed, "Where's my brother?"

Ripples spread across the water.

Hugo was swimming desperately toward shore.

Timothy slammed his fist against the bulkhead. "That lunatic!"

Deep in the jungle,

Hugo wiped seawater from his face.

His fingers tightened around the combat knife stolen from a pirate.

This time, he wouldn't let her face danger alone.
###Chapter 423

Julian Langley's face darkened like a thundercloud.

His knuckles turned white as he clenched his fists, staring in the direction where Hugo Rothschild had disappeared.

That arrogant fool had to cause trouble at the worst possible moment.

Timothy Gold and the crew were organizing the evacuation, returning the guests' confiscated phones.

The moment Julian powered on his device, dozens of missed call notifications flooded the screen.

Before he could even process them, Victoria Langley's call came through.

"Julian!"

Her scream was so piercing he had to hold the phone away to protect his eardrums.

"What kind of brother are you? Letting Evelyn walk straight into danger?"

Victoria's voice cracked with barely restrained sobs.

She knew she shouldn't take it out on her son, but she needed an outlet for her terror.

"Mom, Evelyn knows what she's doing," he said softly. "The military's en route. Me going ashore now would only complicate things."

Muffled weeping filtered through the receiver.

Victoria couldn't erase the images of armed pirates from her mind.

Though the drone footage had been shaky, she'd seen her daughter take down those criminals with lethal precision.

But bullets don't discriminate.

Ethan Sullivan and his team had vanished from the cameras—their fate unknown.

The drones now hid in the treetops, their lenses trembling, one stray shot away from destruction.

"Trust her, Mom." Julian's voice strained. "Ethan and Evelyn will make it back alive."

His fists trembled with suppressed rage.

They were up against ruthless pirates. Three against an army.

And one of those three was dead weight.

But he couldn't voice that thought.

As Richard Langley murmured reassurances, Victoria finally steadied her breathing.

"Whoever dared threaten my daughter on that island," she said, wiping her tears with surgical precision, "will pay in blood."

Each syllable dripped with glacial fury.
###Chapter 424

Victoria Langley's fingers dug into Richard Langley's wrist like talons. "Alert all maritime forces immediately," her voice was glacial. "Shoot those pirates on sight."

Richard stroked his wife's rigid back, his eyes glinting with cold fury. "It's already handled."

Those fools had dared to target his daughter.

The Langley maritime network sprang into action. Within half an hour, the dossier on the "Muller Pirate Crew" lay on Richard's desk.

"Old acquaintances," Richard sneered, dialing a series of encrypted numbers.

Meanwhile, Alexander Langley's global communications network activated. Every vessel with ties to the Muller pirates received an ultimatum—sever all ties immediately or face the Langley Group's full retaliation.

The tides had turned at sea.

Evelyn Laurent remained oblivious.

She moved through the dense jungle like a panther, the briny wind laced with gunpowder stinging her face. Without comms, she relied on primal tracking skills to find Ethan Sullivan.

In the distance, boat engines roared. Reinforcements were closing in.

At least the Southern Cross had escaped the danger zone. Evelyn exhaled slightly—now only she and Ethan remained as targets, simplifying her mission.

Bushes rustled ahead. Evelyn dropped low, holding her breath.

Six pirates shoved through the foliage, cursing, their weapons glinting in the sunlight. Frustration made them sloppy.
